description: Group Policy is an infrastructure that allows you to implement specific configurations for users and computers in a centralized manner. In these episodes, you will learn about configuring and maintaining a Group Policy infrastructure. You will also learn how to specify managed configurations for users and computers through Group Policy settings and Group Policy Preferences. Group Policy will allow you to provide the standardized functionality, security, and management control that your organization needs.

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Wes introduce the basic concepts of Group Policy. They give a high-level overview of the components inside of the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC). They demonstrate how to setup the GPMC on a Windows client so that an employee can perform remote Group Policy management. They talk about how to point the Remote Server Administration Tool (RSAT) to domain controller for the purposes of Group Policy management from a Windows client machine.

00:22:06.113 --> 00:22:10.383
But if I got a policy for my sales
department that handles all the settings

403
00:22:10.383 --> 00:22:14.947

I'm gonna let you be in

00:22:17.806 --> 00:22:19.743
You're in charge of the sales department.

the sales department.

I can create, I can install those

408
00:22:26.047 --> 00:22:28.253
I can give him access to this console.

00:22:28.253 --> 00:22:29.658

410
00:22:29.658 --> 00:22:34.219
Now, I'm logged on as the domain admin,
which is why I get to see everything, and

411
00:22:34.219 --> 00:22:35.555
work with everything.

412
00:22:35.555 --> 00:22:37.010
You can't just download,

413
00:22:37.010 --> 00:22:40.869
like you can't have a user just
download the Remote Server Admin Tools,

414
00:22:40.869 --> 00:22:44.487
and try to connect and start working

415
00:22:44.487 --> 00:22:47.897
There are certain permissions that
are gonna be required in order for

00:22:47.897 --> 00:22:51.679

is another episode we're gonna talk about.

417
00:22:51.679 --> 00:22:54.700

the domain controller itself or

00:22:54.700 --> 00:22:56.634
you can install active directory.

419
00:22:56.634 --> 00:23:00.048
You can manage it remotely from
a server operating system.

00:23:21.094 --> 00:23:26.899

00:23:26.899 --> 00:23:29.803

00:23:36.802 --> 00:23:37.404
>> All right.

Very good.

the Remote Server Administration Tool kit,

00:24:00.721 --> 00:24:02.454
which is a great thing to have.

440
00:24:02.454 --> 00:24:05.132
It doesn't matter if you're on

441
00:24:05.132 --> 00:24:06.916
if you have got a laptop in your cubicle,

00:24:06.916 --> 00:24:10.555

Manage those individual settings within

00:24:19.041 --> 00:24:19.982
All great stuff.

00:24:19.982 --> 00:24:23.744
Okay Mike, you got anything else, anything

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Wes take a deeper look at the anatomy that makes up a Group Policy Object (GPO). They will discuss the components found within the GPO container called Group Policies. They demonstrate computer configurations as well as user settings and define how these settings apply. They introduce policy settings. They will look at how to apply filters to help find settings inside of a GPO.
episodes.title: Group Policy Objects
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.653 --> 00:00:15.636
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:15.636 --> 00:00:17.775
My name is Wes Bryan and
I'm gonna be your host today.

4
00:00:17.775 --> 00:00:21.635
And what we're going into is moving
along and working with Group Policy.

5
00:00:21.635 --> 00:00:25.215
And more specifically today, we're gonna
be talking about Group Policy Objects.

6
00:00:25.215 --> 00:00:27.085
And who better to help
us out with that topic?

7
00:00:27.085 --> 00:00:28.445
None other than Mike Rodrick.

8
00:00:28.445 --> 00:00:29.655
Mike how are you doing today?

9
00:00:29.655 --> 00:00:30.795

I'm glad to be here and
you're absolutely right.

11
00:00:33.075 --> 00:00:37.820
We're gonna be talking about good old
GPOs or Group Policy Objects today.

12
00:00:37.820 --> 00:00:41.270
So, the first thing I wanna do is really
lay down some basic terminology, so

00:00:41.270 --> 00:00:43.240
that we're all on the same page.

Because this is a place where the
terminology does get a little bit fuzzy,

15
00:00:48.270 --> 00:00:50.610
depending on who you're talking to.

16
00:00:50.610 --> 00:00:55.020
It's not that big of a deal, I think
we're all gonna be able to figure it out.

17
00:00:55.020 --> 00:00:56.419
But, let's all make sure
we're on the same page.

18
00:00:57.650 --> 00:01:02.210
So, first I want to define what
a Group Policy Object is, or a GPO.

19
00:01:02.210 --> 00:01:06.680
Because I'm gonna start shortening some

20
00:01:06.680 --> 00:01:11.619
GPO is a Group Policy Object, and
a Group Policy Object is a container.

21
00:01:11.619 --> 00:01:14.414
Right?
It's really not a specific setting.

22
00:01:14.414 --> 00:01:18.915
A group policy object is
a container that contains all of

23
00:01:18.915 --> 00:01:24.203
the different settings that I can
configure using group policy.

24
00:01:24.203 --> 00:01:24.842
Let's take a look.

25
00:01:24.842 --> 00:01:27.394
Let me open up my screen here,
or pull up my computer and

26
00:01:27.394 --> 00:01:29.620
I'm going to open up

27
00:01:29.620 --> 00:01:34.420

00:01:34.420 --> 00:01:36.121
I haven't created any new ones yet.

And I'm just going to take one of those

31
00:01:41.425 --> 00:01:41.993
All right.

32
00:01:41.993 --> 00:01:45.917
And actually before I do that let's go
back and you'll see that where I'm at,

33
00:01:45.917 --> 00:01:49.484
in my Group Policy Management console,
those are the folders called,

34
00:01:49.484 --> 00:01:51.230
Group Policy Objects.

35
00:01:51.230 --> 00:01:53.688
This is where I can find
the different GPO's or

36
00:01:53.688 --> 00:01:57.352
Group Policy Objects that I have
available, or that I've created.

37
00:01:57.352 --> 00:02:00.443
I'm going to right-click
on one of them again and

00:02:00.443 --> 00:02:04.650
choose Edit, and that opens up my
Group Policy Management editor.

39
00:02:04.650 --> 00:02:09.220
So the key here is to remember that

00:02:10.960 --> 00:02:14.060

00:02:14.060 --> 00:02:15.500
choose not to configure, right?

43
00:02:15.500 --> 00:02:21.550
So when I open up this Default Policy,
I see there's two halves.

44
00:02:21.550 --> 00:02:24.540
And I'll collapse them up to make

00:02:24.540 --> 00:02:25.890
There's the Computer Configuration.

00:02:25.890 --> 00:02:28.960
And then there's the User Configuration.

47
00:02:28.960 --> 00:02:34.350
The Computer Configuration, these are
settings that I would apply to a computer.

48
00:02:36.170 --> 00:02:39.940
User configuration, these are settings
that I would apply to a user.

49
00:02:39.940 --> 00:02:40.610
So what am I trying to do?

50
00:02:40.610 --> 00:02:43.260
You know, if you think about if
you apply a setting to a user then

51
00:02:44.540 --> 00:02:49.590
wherever that user goes when they log on
to different machines throughout your

52
00:02:49.590 --> 00:02:51.600
network that setting is
going to follow them, right?

53
00:02:51.600 --> 00:02:53.960
Because you applied
the setting to the user.

54
00:02:53.960 --> 00:02:58.100
If you apply a setting to a computer,
then it's gonna be that machine, and

55
00:02:58.100 --> 00:03:04.040
no matter who logs onto that machine,
that setting's gonna be there.

56
00:03:04.040 --> 00:03:05.730
So what are you trying to do?

57
00:03:05.730 --> 00:03:08.680
If it's a kiosk machine, then you're
probably using computer setting

58
00:03:08.680 --> 00:03:11.530
because you don't know who or
what's gonna log onto there and

59
00:03:11.530 --> 00:03:14.300
you want that setting to
apply no matter who logs on.

60
00:03:14.300 --> 00:03:17.890
If it's a setting that I want Wes to have,
then I want Wes to have that setting

61
00:03:17.890 --> 00:03:22.030
wherever he goes and logs on,

62
00:03:22.030 --> 00:03:24.780
There is some overlap.

63
00:03:24.780 --> 00:03:29.900
There are some settings that you could
do either to a computer or to a user.

64
00:03:29.900 --> 00:03:33.270
So you will find the setting if I

65
00:03:33.270 --> 00:03:35.170
I might find that setting.

66
00:03:35.170 --> 00:03:39.020
I go down to User Configuration, I could
find that same setting because I could

67
00:03:39.020 --> 00:03:43.740
choose to either apply it to the computer
or to the user, others you won't find.

68
00:03:43.740 --> 00:03:46.990
There are some settings that don't
make sense to apply to a computer or

00:03:46.990 --> 00:03:48.960

70
00:03:48.960 --> 00:03:53.742
So figuring out where these
setting are can be a challenge,

71
00:03:53.742 --> 00:03:58.057
but I'll help you out with

72
00:03:58.057 --> 00:04:01.209
All right, so let's talk about
the Computer Configuration

73
00:04:01.209 --> 00:04:03.865
we'll explore some of these
settings in here, and

74
00:04:03.865 --> 00:04:07.600
Wes these again are settings that I
can apply to machines on my network.

75
00:04:07.600 --> 00:04:10.330
>> All right, so now if we're applying
machines on the network, Mike,

76
00:04:10.330 --> 00:04:12.770
right now I know that I'm on your network.

77
00:04:12.770 --> 00:04:14.060
>> Oh, you're in trouble now.

78
00:04:14.060 --> 00:04:16.060
>> Oh yeah, and the question would be,
I think I would have,

00:04:16.060 --> 00:04:19.250
and maybe some of you guys have out there,
when we say applying computer settings,

00:04:19.250 --> 00:04:21.300
do we mean just any computer?

81
00:04:21.300 --> 00:04:22.370
For instance my computer here,

82
00:04:22.370 --> 00:04:25.420
or maybe somebody brings
a computer into your network.

83
00:04:25.420 --> 00:04:28.060
So when you say on the network,
do we have any prerequisites?

84
00:04:28.060 --> 00:04:28.711
Is it any computer?

85
00:04:28.711 --> 00:04:30.744
Is it any user?

86
00:04:30.744 --> 00:04:32.170
So, how does that work for us?

87
00:04:32.170 --> 00:04:33.204
>> That's a great question, Wes.

88
00:04:33.204 --> 00:04:35.492
And when I talk about
computers on my network,

89
00:04:35.492 --> 00:04:37.789
I'm talking about domain machines, right?

90
00:04:37.789 --> 00:04:39.811
Machines that are part of my domain or

91
00:04:39.811 --> 00:04:43.854
possibly part of my force that could be

00:04:43.854 --> 00:04:47.500
they're definitely under
our administrative control.

93
00:04:47.500 --> 00:04:52.210
As far as users go these are users that
have accounted an active directory

00:04:52.210 --> 00:04:55.840
that are logging on to those

95
00:04:55.840 --> 00:04:59.480
So if a vendor brings their laptop in and

00:04:59.480 --> 00:05:03.670

00:05:03.670 --> 00:05:06.983
No, those policies would not apply to him,

98
00:05:06.983 --> 00:05:11.020
neither the computer settings or
the user settings.

99
00:05:11.020 --> 00:05:13.860
But, like I said,
it's a really good question.

100
00:05:13.860 --> 00:05:17.340
Computer settings, when I apply
those to domain based machines,

101
00:05:17.340 --> 00:05:20.360
the machine has to be part of the domain.

102
00:05:20.360 --> 00:05:22.360
It doesn't matter what user logs on.

103
00:05:22.360 --> 00:05:26.620
So domain users as well as local users,

104
00:05:26.620 --> 00:05:30.190
So your user might have a laptop that

00:05:30.190 --> 00:05:32.740

106
00:05:32.740 --> 00:05:36.410

107
00:05:36.410 --> 00:05:39.270
when they take it home or
whatever their not doing work things.

108
00:05:39.270 --> 00:05:43.060
Well those settings would still
apply to that local user.

109
00:05:43.060 --> 00:05:46.500
So your users aren't gonna be able to get
around your settings that you're applying

110
00:05:46.500 --> 00:05:50.420
with the group policy by trying
to log on with a local account.

111
00:05:50.420 --> 00:05:53.520
Those computer settings apply to that

112
00:05:53.520 --> 00:05:56.780
And here's why, there's actually
a really good, easy explanation.

113
00:05:56.780 --> 00:06:00.120
Those settings are applied
before the user ever logs on.

114
00:06:00.120 --> 00:06:04.000
We're gonna talk about that, that's
an important part to understand is when

115
00:06:04.000 --> 00:06:07.480
those settings are applied, but
I'll go ahead and give you a heads up.

116
00:06:07.480 --> 00:06:10.860
Computer settings are applied
when that computer

117
00:06:10.860 --> 00:06:13.710
starts up well before you
ever get the log on screen.

118
00:06:13.710 --> 00:06:16.080
So it doesn't matter if you're
logging on with a main account or

119
00:06:16.080 --> 00:06:18.180
if you're logging on with a local account.

120
00:06:18.180 --> 00:06:20.230
Those settings are gonna be in place.

121
00:06:20.230 --> 00:06:23.792
So that's a great question there Wes.

122
00:06:23.792 --> 00:06:27.360
All right so lets take a look, lets dive
a little bit further into this GPO and

00:06:27.360 --> 00:06:31.010

00:06:31.010 --> 00:06:33.390
I'm gonna start under

00:06:43.350 --> 00:06:45.050
We've had policies or setting, right?

00:06:49.380 --> 00:06:53.798
that's where it gets a little bit

00:06:53.798 --> 00:07:00.660
I sometimes like to think of

00:07:00.660 --> 00:07:02.690
But that's where you've go to be careful.

00:07:02.690 --> 00:07:08.205
This whole thing, the default domain

00:07:08.205 --> 00:07:13.905
Each individual setting,

00:07:13.905 --> 00:07:16.690

00:07:16.690 --> 00:07:17.990
I don't care what you call it.

00:07:17.990 --> 00:07:22.120
And most of your people that you work

00:07:22.120 --> 00:07:24.320

00:07:24.320 --> 00:07:27.180
If you're gonna go take an exam,

00:07:27.180 --> 00:07:29.060

141
00:07:29.060 --> 00:07:31.450
Then understand according to Microsoft,

00:07:31.450 --> 00:07:35.110
the whole container is
a Group Policy Object.

143
00:07:35.110 --> 00:07:39.933
Each setting within is a Group Policy or
a Group Policy setting, right?

144
00:07:39.933 --> 00:07:43.498
>> One of the things I was saying,
I know that you've been

00:08:02.501 --> 00:08:06.072
Active directory as we know today

00:08:06.072 --> 00:08:09.174
And then there's all these other branches,

more of a generalization when

We have to say we're talking about domain
services, and all the other things that go

00:08:18.670 --> 00:08:21.710
along with active directory

158
00:08:21.710 --> 00:08:25.349
>> And like I said, if you're taking
an active Microsoft certification,

159
00:08:25.349 --> 00:08:27.566
then that terminology really becomes key.

160
00:08:27.566 --> 00:08:29.972
You've got to make sure

161
00:08:29.972 --> 00:08:32.363
If we're out there working
in the real world,

00:08:32.363 --> 00:08:34.826
you've got a little bit
of flexibility there.

163
00:08:34.826 --> 00:08:37.857
All right so let's continue on with our
investigation of this Group Policy Object.

164
00:08:37.857 --> 00:08:39.805
As I said, it's divided up into two parts.

165
00:08:39.805 --> 00:08:40.800
You've got your Computer Configuration.

166
00:08:40.800 --> 00:08:43.300
You've got your User Configuration.

167
00:08:43.300 --> 00:08:45.900
Underneath computer,
I've got Policies and Preferences.

168
00:08:45.900 --> 00:08:51.010
Underneath user I've got Policies and

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Wes take a look at what it takes to create and deploy a Group Policy Object with an Active Directory domain. They discuss how to create a GPO through the Group Policy Management Console and also through the Windows PowerShell. They talk about how GPOs are stored in two different locations inside of Active Directory and how this effects the application of policy settings. Permissions are another component of GPOs that can affect how policy settings are applied. Mike and Wes will discuss where to set permissions when it comes to delegation and application of GPOs. They show you where you can edit and link GPOs to push out configurations to users and computers in a Windows Active Directory domain

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Wes demonstrate a component in Group Policy called Administrative Templates. They show you how to configure administrative templates and where the administrative templates are stored. They look at what makes up an administrative template by discussing settings files called ADMX files are and their associated language files called ADML files. They demonstrate how to import ADMX and ADML files to extend the configurations of the administrative templates. They take a look at setting up a centralized location to store ADMX files for all domain controllers within the domain through the Central Store.

episodes.description: Group policy contains thousands of settings that can apply to thousands of user or computers. In this episode Mike and Wes look at how to scope Group Policy Objects(GPOs) to specific users and/or computers inside of a Windows domain. They talk about what a link is, how it applies to GPOs and where you can apply them in the Group Policy Management Console(GMPC). They discuss the difference between a container, an organizational unit and where you would use these. They talk about the precedence GPOs used to apply settings.

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Wes take a continued look at scoping Group Policy Objects (GPOs) to specific users and computers. They look at the processing order that Group Policy uses to determine which settings will be applied and how Group Policy handles settings conflicts. They discuss Group Policy inheritance and how to block settings from being inherited and enforce settings in Active Directory. They talk about when Group Policy settings apply and how to force the application of Group Policy settings through GPUpdate with the "force". They talk about the components that apply the settings found in a GPOS call Client-side Extensions(CSEs)

Because I knew that logging, it was a user
setting in the GPO and I knew that logging

534
00:29:51.881 --> 00:29:55.676
off and logging back on would
trigger that refresh policy right,

535
00:29:55.676 --> 00:29:59.833
because I know that the user settings
are applied when the user logs on.

536
00:29:59.833 --> 00:30:02.993
But that's not the only way
that I can refresh settings.

537
00:30:02.993 --> 00:30:05.407
We can log off, if it's a user setting.

538
00:30:05.407 --> 00:30:09.308
I can logoff and log back on,
I could wait 90 minutes or

539
00:30:09.308 --> 00:30:14.537
I can open up a command prompt and
do what's called a group policy refresh or

540
00:30:14.537 --> 00:30:16.880
GP update is the actual command.

541
00:30:16.880 --> 00:30:20.154
Same thing for the computer settings.

542
00:30:20.154 --> 00:30:21.456
We can force it.

543
00:30:21.456 --> 00:30:23.824
Let's say, like we just did.

544
00:30:23.824 --> 00:30:28.310
I didn't want to wait around 90 to
120 minutes, so I chose to logoff and

545
00:30:28.310 --> 00:30:29.420
log back on.

546
00:30:29.420 --> 00:30:32.820
If it was a machine setting,
I could have rebooted the machine, but

547
00:30:32.820 --> 00:30:34.083
what if I can't do that?

548
00:30:34.083 --> 00:30:39.434
What if I want to test the setting right
now, I don't wanna wait 90 to 120 minutes.

549
00:30:39.434 --> 00:30:43.275
I can't reboot the machine, because other
people are also, say, it was the server.

550
00:30:43.275 --> 00:30:45.950
Other people are connected to it and
they're accessing files and

551
00:30:45.950 --> 00:30:49.170
things like that, so I can't just reboot
that server in the middle of the day.

552
00:30:49.170 --> 00:30:52.311
Or if its a user system, they might be
in the middle of doing something and

553
00:30:52.311 --> 00:30:54.125
I can't just reboot that system on them.

554
00:30:54.125 --> 00:31:00.235
That's where we get GP update and
I can show you.

555
00:31:00.235 --> 00:31:04.091
Lets do this, lets change screensaver.

556
00:31:04.091 --> 00:31:08.781
I'm gonna unenforce this guy,
we'll take away that.

557
00:31:08.781 --> 00:31:12.257
So at this point, we're blocking
inheritance, the developers are should.

558
00:31:12.257 --> 00:31:17.135
The only policy that they are and we can
refresh this window to show you that.

559
00:31:17.135 --> 00:31:21.563
So dev policy should be the only one in
effect, that setting, that screensaver

560
00:31:21.563 --> 00:31:26.277
time out to, gosh, I forget what we've
done now, 600 seconds or 10 minutes.

561
00:31:26.277 --> 00:31:29.372
But if I go back over
here to Rob's machine and

562
00:31:29.372 --> 00:31:34.918
I look at the screensaver timeout,
it's actually already down to ten minutes.

563
00:31:34.918 --> 00:31:35.525
Nice.

564
00:31:35.525 --> 00:31:38.900
It might have done a refresh
recycle in the background on me,

565
00:31:38.900 --> 00:31:40.165
as we were doing that.

566
00:31:40.165 --> 00:31:41.233
Let's do this.

567
00:31:41.233 --> 00:31:43.930
Let's go to that dev policy.

568
00:31:43.930 --> 00:31:47.516
Oh, no, I take that back,
they were 20 minutes.

569
00:31:47.516 --> 00:31:48.402
Was that right, Wes?

570
00:31:48.402 --> 00:31:51.421
10 minutes for everybody,
20 minutes for the development team.

571
00:31:51.421 --> 00:31:52.846
That's right.
I'm losing track of what

572
00:31:52.846 --> 00:31:53.750
the heck I'm doing.

573
00:31:53.750 --> 00:31:59.011
So notice it's still at 10 minutes even
though I've just removed that policy,

574
00:31:59.011 --> 00:32:04.070
because the last time it applied applied
settings is said to be 20 minutes.

575
00:32:04.070 --> 00:32:05.523
I've removed the policy.

576
00:32:05.523 --> 00:32:07.475
Now I could log off and log back on, but

577
00:32:07.475 --> 00:32:09.980
what if Rob was in the middle
of doing something?

578
00:32:09.980 --> 00:32:14.084
He had some program running in the
background that he needed to finish and

579
00:32:14.084 --> 00:32:18.271
I can't just log him off, but
I don't wanna wait 90 to 120 minutes.

580
00:32:18.271 --> 00:32:24.457
I can open up a command prompt and
I can do what we call a GP update,

581
00:32:24.457 --> 00:32:31.350
that's GP group policy GP/ and
then I'm going to do what call a force.

582
00:32:31.350 --> 00:32:33.394
I'll explain that in
a minute as that refreshes.

583
00:32:33.394 --> 00:32:37.852
Let me bump up my font, so you guys can
see what I'm typing in the results here.

584
00:32:41.387 --> 00:32:46.334
So I type in gpupdate /force and
notice it says, Computer Policy update

585
00:32:46.334 --> 00:32:50.891
completed successfully,
User Policy completed successfully.

586
00:32:50.891 --> 00:32:55.807
So, I'm just manually triggering that
refresh process that normally occurs at 90

587
00:32:55.807 --> 00:32:56.978
to 120 minutes.

588
00:32:56.978 --> 00:33:01.412
I right-click and I take a look at
personalize, I go to Screensaver.

589
00:33:01.412 --> 00:33:02.610
Notice now it's back to 20 minutes.

590
00:33:04.030 --> 00:33:08.168
It would have eventually gone to 20
minutes anyway at the normal refresh

591
00:33:08.168 --> 00:33:11.048
cycle, but
that's just that way I can speed it up.

592
00:33:11.048 --> 00:33:16.017
Now that force option, what that does,
you can do a GP update without force and

593
00:33:16.017 --> 00:33:20.611
it does a normal refresh, which means
only policies that have changed or

594
00:33:20.611 --> 00:33:22.062
new would be applied.

595
00:33:22.062 --> 00:33:26.938
Force says, reapply all policies
whether they've changed or not.

596
00:33:26.938 --> 00:33:31.207
And I just know from personal experience
with Windows that sometimes if I do it

597
00:33:31.207 --> 00:33:34.238
without the force,
it doesn't seem to apply policy.

598
00:33:34.238 --> 00:33:38.610
Even though the policy has changed,
it doesn't seem to detect it and apply it.

599
00:33:38.610 --> 00:33:41.758
If I do force, it applies all policies,
changed or not and

600
00:33:41.758 --> 00:33:44.279
I can get that setting to
kick in like I like it.

601
00:33:44.279 --> 00:33:45.255
>> Very good.

602
00:33:45.255 --> 00:33:46.741
A lot of good information, Mike.

603
00:33:46.741 --> 00:33:47.762
Thank you for that.

604
00:33:47.762 --> 00:33:51.980
Looks like we're going to be going
into a part three on this one guys,

605
00:33:51.980 --> 00:33:55.273
as we've definitely come
to the end of this episode.

606
00:33:55.273 --> 00:33:59.319
So if you haven't seen some of the earlier
episodes, go back and watch them.

607
00:33:59.319 --> 00:34:03.743
But we've talked about things like
the inheritance, enforcing your links,

608
00:34:03.743 --> 00:34:04.958
the layered policy.

609
00:34:04.958 --> 00:34:05.919
And hopefully,

610
00:34:05.919 --> 00:34:10.384
this is gonna help you get the recipe,
your group policy cookbook out there.

611
00:34:10.384 --> 00:34:13.031
Mike, any other words for
this episode here?

612
00:34:13.031 --> 00:34:14.796
>> No, I've still got a lot to say.

613
00:34:14.796 --> 00:34:16.007
[LAUGH] So we'll just save it for
the next time.

614
00:34:16.007 --> 00:34:17.079
[LAUGH]
>> There we go.

615
00:34:17.079 --> 00:34:19.915
Well, we're gonna go ahead and
sign off for this one.

616
00:34:19.915 --> 00:34:21.312
I've been your host, Wes Brian.

617
00:34:21.312 --> 00:34:22.380
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

618
00:34:22.380 --> 00:34:23.963
>> And we'll see you next time.

619
00:34:23.963 --> 00:34:30.811
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Wes take a continued look at scoping Group Policy Objects (GPOs) to specific users and computers. They look at how to determine what settings are currently configured in a Group Policy Object (GPO). They talk about the what slow link detection and how it effect the application of GPOs.
episodes.title: Group Policy Scope Part 3

WEBVTT

1

The site policies, then the domain

this OU, so there's a lot to it,

>> That's right,
we'll toss that in this one as well.

22
00:01:17.500 --> 00:01:22.297
So first thing I want to talk
about though is the whole,

00:01:22.297 --> 00:01:25.018
what's a good way to say that.

24
00:01:25.018 --> 00:01:27.647
You guys remember, well, let's go
look at it, let me go back over here.

25
00:01:27.647 --> 00:01:31.872
I'm logged on as Rob, and I'm gonna pull
up those screen saver setting again.

00:01:31.872 --> 00:01:35.286
Remember in part two,
we applied a couple settings.

00:01:35.286 --> 00:01:40.077
We set the screen saver time out for those
developer's OU to be 1,200 seconds, or

20 minutes.

00:01:41.290 --> 00:01:45.240
And sure enough, it is, right?

I can't click on that, it's grayed out.

And this is an important part

00:01:53.948 --> 00:01:58.024
the fact that they are what

00:01:58.024 --> 00:02:02.574
If I've got a setting that I want to
apply to all those machines out there, or

00:02:02.574 --> 00:02:06.698
all those users out there, or
just a few users in the Development OU,

00:02:06.698 --> 00:02:11.269
those are settings that, as a company,

00:02:11.269 --> 00:02:15.130
I don't want my end users going around and

What if I've got a policy that's
creating firewall exceptions, or

00:02:18.436 --> 00:02:22.485
blocking certain ports, and the user says,
you know what, I don't wanna do that.

00:02:22.485 --> 00:02:25.066
That breaks my game that I wanna
play in the middle of the day.

00:02:25.066 --> 00:02:28.682
I'm gonna go ahead and
uncheck that or undo that setting.

00:02:28.682 --> 00:02:31.176
They cannot when we use policies,

43
00:02:31.176 --> 00:02:36.687
those settings are what we call enforced,
and it locks the user interface.

44
00:02:36.687 --> 00:02:40.647
Now, you'll see I can still pick
what screensaver I want because

45
00:02:40.647 --> 00:02:43.534
the policy didn't specify
what screensaver.

00:02:43.534 --> 00:02:48.206
And evidently on that dev policy, I also

00:02:48.206 --> 00:02:50.596
So let's go change a couple

00:02:50.596 --> 00:02:52.412
see how that affects this machine here.

49
00:02:52.412 --> 00:02:57.076
I'm going to flip back over, and
remember we've got the screensaver

00:02:57.076 --> 00:03:01.583
settings up here, which is applying
that ten minute screensaver,

51
00:03:01.583 --> 00:03:04.684
as well as password
protect the screensaver.

52

Now a little side note here,
let's take a quick detour and

talk about how I can figure out what
settings are involved in these policies,

00:03:13.424 --> 00:03:16.427
because that's a challenge in and

55
00:03:16.427 --> 00:03:19.793
Like I'm sitting here, you see me
struggling through this show going, wait,

00:03:19.793 --> 00:03:21.059

00:03:21.059 --> 00:03:24.208

Especially if you've got dozens and

00:03:28.096 --> 00:03:31.261
Especially if you weren't the one

00:03:31.261 --> 00:03:33.419
how do you know what

Well, I'll tell you, with this new group
policy management console, and I say new,

00:03:37.853 --> 00:03:39.941
it actually came out in circa 2003.

00:03:39.941 --> 00:03:44.415
But prior to that, it was a nightmare,
because what we would have to do is we

00:03:44.415 --> 00:03:47.338
would have to make nice
comments on everything.

00:03:47.338 --> 00:03:51.333
When I take a look at this GPO,
if I edit this GPO,

00:03:51.333 --> 00:03:56.317
there's actually a way that we

00:03:56.317 --> 00:03:59.272
And it's been so long since I've

00:03:59.272 --> 00:04:04.340
I can go to the comments and I could

00:04:04.340 --> 00:04:08.840
Like say, hey, this policy applies

71
00:04:08.840 --> 00:04:12.511
The password to protect the screensaver,
you have to document everything,

00:04:12.511 --> 00:04:16.080
and of course, as admins, we know
we're all a little bit lazy sometimes.

73
00:04:16.080 --> 00:04:19.820
If you didn't document it, the only other
way to figure out what settings were in

74
00:04:19.820 --> 00:04:23.177
there would be to actually to start
opening this up and looking through.

75
00:04:23.177 --> 00:04:27.908
And you're not going to scroll through
4,000 plus settings trying to figure out

76
00:04:27.908 --> 00:04:29.889
what some other admin did, right?

00:04:29.889 --> 00:04:31.400
It was a nightmare.

78
00:04:31.400 --> 00:04:35.000
Now though, starting again with 2003,

79
00:04:35.000 --> 00:04:37.930
we've got this in this group
policy management console.

00:04:37.930 --> 00:04:39.621
We get this settings tab.

00:04:39.621 --> 00:04:41.544
And I can go to this settings tab,

00:04:41.544 --> 00:04:46.305
and my IE settings are a little bit harsh,

83
00:04:46.305 --> 00:04:49.149
And here, I'm just gonna go ahead and

00:04:49.149 --> 00:04:52.480
I can see exactly what settings
out of those 4,000 plus

00:04:52.480 --> 00:04:55.022

00:04:55.022 --> 00:04:58.130
The ones that are not configured

00:04:58.130 --> 00:05:02.163

00:05:02.163 --> 00:05:03.291

00:05:03.291 --> 00:05:07.142
And there I can see, password protect
the screensaver is turned on, and

00:05:07.142 --> 00:05:11.011

91
00:05:11.011 --> 00:05:15.337
Fantastic, love, I mean this is, when
this came out, the admins that were in

00:05:15.337 --> 00:05:19.158
the field already were just like

00:05:19.158 --> 00:05:20.898
Now if I go to that default domain policy,

what the heck is in

00:05:22.856 --> 00:05:24.940
Oh, I can find out.

00:05:24.940 --> 00:05:28.751
I can see all the settings that are
configured in that default domain policy

00:05:28.751 --> 00:05:29.669

00:05:29.669 --> 00:05:32.624
So it's a beautiful thing.

99
00:05:32.624 --> 00:05:36.829
All right,
I'm gonna undo this blocking inheritance.

100
00:05:36.829 --> 00:05:42.749
So now at the developer's OU, all of

101
00:05:42.749 --> 00:05:46.643

my screensaver settings.

00:05:46.643 --> 00:05:51.968
But because the domain policy said, or

00:05:51.968 --> 00:05:57.692
seconds, but the dev policy says 1,200
seconds for that screensaver timeout,

00:05:57.692 --> 00:06:02.240

00:06:02.240 --> 00:06:06.422
I should also have a password protect

00:06:06.422 --> 00:06:11.315

00:06:11.315 --> 00:06:14.748
All right, so

00:06:14.748 --> 00:06:16.299
Clear the block inheritance,

00:06:16.299 --> 00:06:19.828

00:06:19.828 --> 00:06:24.036
At the domain level, I've got the 600

00:06:24.036 --> 00:06:26.095

00:06:31.194 --> 00:06:35.928

00:06:35.928 --> 00:06:40.466
So when I unblock that inheritance,

00:06:40.466 --> 00:06:44.481

00:06:44.481 --> 00:06:49.304
I am gonna cancel that and

00:06:49.304 --> 00:06:55.533

00:07:14.926 --> 00:07:17.731

00:07:17.731 --> 00:07:20.470

00:07:20.470 --> 00:07:24.021

00:07:24.021 --> 00:07:28.042

00:07:28.042 --> 00:07:31.145

00:07:31.145 --> 00:07:35.395

00:07:35.395 --> 00:07:38.701

Right?

134
00:07:47.435 --> 00:07:48.025
Right?

135
00:07:48.025 --> 00:07:52.289
I can change the screensaver, cuz the
policy didn't specify anything about what

136
00:07:52.289 --> 00:07:55.461
screensaver I had to use, but
I cannot change this, right?

137
00:07:55.461 --> 00:07:59.747
So that's the thing about those policies
that says the setting is enforced.

138
00:07:59.747 --> 00:08:03.887
The users cannot, even if I'm an admin,
even if I was the domain admin, in fact,

139
00:08:03.887 --> 00:08:05.091
here, I'll show you.

140
00:08:05.091 --> 00:08:08.179
Let's log off here.

141
00:08:08.179 --> 00:08:13.929
And we'll just, da, da,
da, we'll sign out.

142
00:08:13.929 --> 00:08:18.216
And I'll log back on as the domain admin.

143
00:08:18.216 --> 00:08:19.374
I could do whatever I want.

144
00:08:19.374 --> 00:08:21.242
I'm the domain admin, right?

145
00:08:21.242 --> 00:08:27.582
Well, let's see, personalize,
screensaver, and negative.

146
00:08:27.582 --> 00:08:29.369
Notice it's ten minutes for

147
00:08:29.369 --> 00:08:33.027
the domain admin because I'm
not in the developer's OU.

148
00:08:33.027 --> 00:08:37.736
So that policy that set it to 20
minutes doesn't apply to me, right,

149
00:08:37.736 --> 00:08:40.178
when I log onto this machine, okay?

150
00:08:40.178 --> 00:08:43.104
All right, so they are enforced.

151
00:08:43.104 --> 00:08:47.941
They are also, another thing we need
to understand about these policies is

152
00:08:47.941 --> 00:08:51.495
that if I fall out of scope,
the policy will be undone.

153
00:08:51.495 --> 00:08:55.577
In other words,
let's see how I could show you this,

154
00:08:55.577 --> 00:08:59.499
I'm going to just delete that policy,
all right?

155
00:08:59.499 --> 00:09:01.938
So right now,
I'm logged on as a domain admin.

156
00:09:01.938 --> 00:09:06.549
Ten minutes screensaver time out, on
resume password protect the screensaver.

157
00:09:06.549 --> 00:09:10.054
Flip back over here to my
domain controller, and

158
00:09:10.054 --> 00:09:13.650
rather than delete it,
I'm going to disable it.

159
00:09:13.650 --> 00:09:17.877
Something else we didn't talk about, the
property of the link, I can enable it or

160
00:09:17.877 --> 00:09:18.563
disable it.

161
00:09:18.563 --> 00:09:21.511
If I'm doing this,
is especially useful for troubleshooting,

162
00:09:21.511 --> 00:09:24.725
trying to figure out what, if I think
this policy is causing a problem,

163
00:09:24.725 --> 00:09:26.508
I can come in here and disable the link.

164
00:09:26.508 --> 00:09:31.012
Remember the link is separate from the
GPO, so if this policy was linked to four

165
00:09:31.012 --> 00:09:35.874
different places, I could disable the link
in one place but not the others, right?

166
00:09:35.874 --> 00:09:36.654
They're independent.

167
00:09:36.654 --> 00:09:38.077
They're their own objects.

168
00:09:38.077 --> 00:09:40.210
But now that policy's turned off.

169
00:09:40.210 --> 00:09:46.935
So if I come back over here and
I refresh policy again.

170
00:09:46.935 --> 00:09:54.159
A little gpupdate switch force,
we'll let that policy refresh,

171
00:09:54.159 --> 00:10:02.031
so the policy should no longer be
applied because it has been turned off.

172
00:10:02.031 --> 00:10:06.155
There we go, we'll go to screensaver, and
now I'm back to the default domain policy.

173
00:10:06.155 --> 00:10:11.661
One minute screensaver out, and I can
change this one if I want, all right?

174
00:10:11.661 --> 00:10:18.528
So it's no longer in effect because
the policy is no longer being applied.

175
00:10:18.528 --> 00:10:23.998
So, with policies, they're enforced, but
if the policy falls out of scope, if I

176
00:10:23.998 --> 00:10:29.723
move Rob out of the developer's OU, well,
that policy should no longer apply to him.

177
00:10:29.723 --> 00:10:32.851
He won't have that 20 minute
screensaver time out anymore, right?

178
00:10:32.851 --> 00:10:36.285
Because it's now out of scope for
Rob's account.

179
00:10:36.285 --> 00:10:39.617
And that's different from preferences.

180
00:10:39.617 --> 00:10:41.648
Now, we haven't played
a lot with preferences yet.

181
00:10:41.648 --> 00:10:44.897
We're gonna spend a good amount
of time on those preferences, but

182
00:10:44.897 --> 00:10:46.533
let's open up this policy here.

183
00:10:46.533 --> 00:10:50.811
I'm gonna choose Edit, and remember,
underneath Computer, I've got Policies and

184
00:10:50.811 --> 00:10:52.048
I've got Preferences.

185
00:10:52.048 --> 00:10:56.171
Under User, I've got Policies and
I've got Preferences, all right?

186
00:10:56.171 --> 00:10:58.265
Policies are enforced.

187
00:10:58.265 --> 00:11:02.327
They're going to lock the user interface,
but if the policy no longer applies to

188
00:11:02.327 --> 00:11:06.228
you, it will undo the lock, and it will
let you change it again if you want to.

189
00:11:06.228 --> 00:11:09.195
Preferences don't block
the user interface.

190
00:11:09.195 --> 00:11:10.739
They're not enforced.

191
00:11:10.739 --> 00:11:15.192
I can create a setting using a preference,
have it applied to you just like a policy,

192
00:11:15.192 --> 00:11:17.403
but it doesn't lock the user interface.

193
00:11:17.403 --> 00:11:21.131
So if you wanna undo the setting,
you're welcome to, but

194
00:11:21.131 --> 00:11:23.579
it tattoos the registry, all right?

195
00:11:23.579 --> 00:11:27.035
In other words, if I delete the policy or
I remove the policy, or

196
00:11:27.035 --> 00:11:30.691
it goes out of scope,
it doesn't automatically undo the setting.

197
00:11:30.691 --> 00:11:34.754
Again, the interface isn't locked so the
user can undo the setting any time they

198
00:11:34.754 --> 00:11:38.533
want, but group policy itself is not
going to go back and undo the setting.

199
00:11:38.533 --> 00:11:41.601
Once it applies a preference,
it says all right, there it is.

200
00:11:41.601 --> 00:11:45.936
I'm gonna make that setting in the
registry and even if the policy goes away,

201
00:11:45.936 --> 00:11:49.146
that setting is still there
in the registry, all right?

202
00:11:49.146 --> 00:11:53.629
So key difference between policy
settings and preferences,

203
00:11:53.629 --> 00:11:55.964
policy settings are enforced.

204
00:11:55.964 --> 00:11:58.156
They lock the user interface, but

205
00:11:58.156 --> 00:12:01.794
they will be unlocked when
the policy falls out of scope.

206
00:12:01.794 --> 00:12:04.233
Preferences doesn't lock
the user interface.

207
00:12:04.233 --> 00:12:08.661
They're not enforced, but it does
remain even if the policy is removed.

208
00:12:08.661 --> 00:12:12.664
You would have to manually remove or
undo that setting.

209
00:12:12.664 --> 00:12:13.517
>> That sounds really good.

210
00:12:13.517 --> 00:12:17.570
So if you wanna maybe deploy an initial
setting but it's not something that's so

211
00:12:17.570 --> 00:12:21.265
detrimental that you don't mind users
changing it, they can modify it,

212
00:12:21.265 --> 00:12:22.831
not saying it's a good thing.

213
00:12:22.831 --> 00:12:24.790
>> Right.
>> But they would have that ability.

214
00:12:24.790 --> 00:12:29.131
>> Yeah, I've worked in an environment
where we pushed out power options.

215
00:12:29.131 --> 00:12:33.121
There are power plants through preferences
because we wanted to make sure that

216
00:12:33.121 --> 00:12:37.110
the screens were going to sleep after
a certain amount of time, the hard drives

217
00:12:37.110 --> 00:12:40.632
were turning off after a certain
amount of time, trying to be green.

218
00:12:40.632 --> 00:12:42.903
But some of the people on my network,

219
00:12:42.903 --> 00:12:46.584
they needed their machine to stay up,
like hosts, right?

220
00:12:46.584 --> 00:12:49.977
I can't have my computer going to
sleep in the middle of a show.

221
00:12:49.977 --> 00:12:53.147
So that ten minutes and
it goes to sleep isn't gonna work for me.

222
00:12:53.147 --> 00:12:57.352
Because it was a preference, I could go
in there and change that on my machine.

223
00:12:57.352 --> 00:12:59.433
It's not locking that user interface.

224
00:12:59.433 --> 00:13:03.015
>> Sure, so you might have somebody that's
working nine to five, right, that maybe

225
00:13:03.015 --> 00:13:06.612
you have a second set of people that come
in and they're working a little bit later.

226
00:13:06.612 --> 00:13:10.221
That policy, if it was enforced, would
probably be a little detrimental to their

227
00:13:10.221 --> 00:13:13.830
productivity for the night staff, and it
gives them the option if they want to turn

228
00:13:13.830 --> 00:13:15.742
around and
modify it later if they need to.

229
00:13:15.742 --> 00:13:17.186
>> That's exactly right, got you.

230
00:13:17.186 --> 00:13:20.018
>> All right, now the other thing we want
to talk about here is those good old

231
00:13:20.018 --> 00:13:21.046
client side extensions.

232
00:13:21.046 --> 00:13:25.001
We've mentioned them once before,
we said that CSE, that's the acronym

233
00:13:25.001 --> 00:13:29.234
they're gonna use for client side
extensions, reside on the client machine.

234
00:13:29.234 --> 00:13:32.484
Also remember, I'm not talking
about client operating system.

235
00:13:32.484 --> 00:13:36.272
Every Windows operating system
has these client side extensions,

236
00:13:36.272 --> 00:13:39.535
server operating systems,
even my domain controllers.

237
00:13:39.535 --> 00:13:41.565
Because policy applies to them, right?

238
00:13:41.565 --> 00:13:45.609
So they have it, and
the CSC is what processes the policies.

239
00:13:45.609 --> 00:13:47.161
When we talk Active Directory,

240
00:13:47.161 --> 00:13:50.038
we get the list of policies
that's supposed to be applied.

241
00:13:50.038 --> 00:13:54.366
It's to the CSE, the client side
extension, that reads the policy and

242
00:13:54.366 --> 00:13:57.047
actually makes the change in the registry.

243
00:13:57.047 --> 00:13:57.698
All right.

244
00:13:57.698 --> 00:14:01.049
Now, these client side extensions have
some default behaviors associated

245
00:14:01.049 --> 00:14:01.579
with them.

246
00:14:01.579 --> 00:14:07.096
Most settings when you refresh policy,
if they're changed or

247
00:14:07.096 --> 00:14:12.102
if there's a new policy,
they're gonna reapply them.

248
00:14:12.102 --> 00:14:18.970
If we do the GP update force,
it reapplies all those settings.

249
00:14:18.970 --> 00:14:22.972
There are some, however,
that don't apply on the refresh cycle.

250
00:14:22.972 --> 00:14:26.730
And I'm not talking about me running it or
doing a manual refresh.

251
00:14:26.730 --> 00:14:28.092
I'm talking about normal, right?

252
00:14:28.092 --> 00:14:32.200
You start the machine up and
then every 90 to 120 minutes,

253
00:14:32.200 --> 00:14:34.880
it's gonna reapply policies, right?

254
00:14:34.880 --> 00:14:37.880
If he's logged on,
every 90 to 120 minutes later,

255
00:14:37.880 --> 00:14:42.170
it's gonna refresh or
reapply those policies, except for a few.

256
00:14:42.170 --> 00:14:46.532
There's folder redirection,
that only applies when you log on.

257
00:14:46.532 --> 00:14:49.722
It doesn't reapply every refresh cycle.

258
00:14:49.722 --> 00:14:52.947
Software installation only
runs when you log on,

259
00:14:52.947 --> 00:14:55.879
it doesn't apply during the refresh cycle.

260
00:14:55.879 --> 00:14:59.840
Some of them don't apply based
on the link that you have.

261
00:14:59.840 --> 00:15:02.765
And let me use a different word,
because we've been using link a lot,

262
00:15:02.765 --> 00:15:04.412
the connection that you have, right?

263
00:15:04.412 --> 00:15:08.170
Let's say that I've got a policy
that installs Office, all right?

264
00:15:08.170 --> 00:15:11.994
That's a good thing, I don't have to
run around from machine to machine and

265
00:15:11.994 --> 00:15:12.904
install Office.

266
00:15:12.904 --> 00:15:17.052
What if Wes is on his laptop, I make
this policy, Wes happens to dial in,

267
00:15:17.052 --> 00:15:21.133
he's on a road trip, he's doing some
videos out in another location.

268
00:15:21.133 --> 00:15:25.930
He has a connection back to work, but
it's a nice low dial-up connection.

269
00:15:25.930 --> 00:15:30.548
Do I really wanna try to push out
Office across that dial-up connection?

270
00:15:30.548 --> 00:15:35.361
Well, group policy does what
we call slow link detection,

271
00:15:35.361 --> 00:15:39.696
and by default,
it's 500 kilobits per second and

272
00:15:39.696 --> 00:15:45.784
some of those client side extensions
won't fire if it detects a slow link.

273
00:15:45.784 --> 00:15:49.523
And that's a good thing, but
we can change that if we need to.

274
00:15:49.523 --> 00:15:52.081
I might wanna force that
software to install,

275
00:15:52.081 --> 00:15:53.993
whether you got a slow link or not.

276
00:15:53.993 --> 00:15:57.020
Or I can change what a slow link is,
right?

277
00:15:57.020 --> 00:15:59.364
I don't have to stick with
that 500 kilobits per second.

278
00:15:59.364 --> 00:16:02.738
Let me pull up, well,
we got a policy open right here.

279
00:16:02.738 --> 00:16:06.226
I'm just going to expand
our computer configuration,

280
00:16:06.226 --> 00:16:10.691
administrative templates, system,
and then group policy, right?

281
00:16:10.691 --> 00:16:15.099
And if we look in here,
let's see if I can find it real quick.

282
00:16:15.099 --> 00:16:18.750
Wes, there's a lot of settings in here.

283
00:16:18.750 --> 00:16:25.150
Bum, bum, bum, bum, configure your
slow link detection, there we go.

284
00:16:25.150 --> 00:16:28.760
So this one is what specifies
what a slow link is.

285
00:16:28.760 --> 00:16:32.654
I can turn this on and
notice the default is 500.

286
00:16:32.654 --> 00:16:37.594
Maybe I wanna say anything slower
than 1,500 kilobits per second

287
00:16:37.594 --> 00:16:40.029
should be considered a slow link.

288
00:16:40.029 --> 00:16:42.753
So I can change what a slow link is, and

289
00:16:42.753 --> 00:16:47.790
that would in turn change the client
side exchange behavior, right?

290
00:16:47.790 --> 00:16:52.205
Now, all of a sudden, if you don't have
at least 1,500 kilobits per second,

291
00:16:52.205 --> 00:16:54.170
that software CSE is not gonna fire.

292
00:16:54.170 --> 00:17:00.549
So I can change what a slow link is or
I can change the CSE behavior itself.

293
00:17:00.549 --> 00:17:05.242
There's a CSE for each major
category of settings in that GPO.

294
00:17:05.242 --> 00:17:07.213
Like there's one for ip security.

295
00:17:07.213 --> 00:17:10.565
There's one for the registry settings
on my administrative templates.

296
00:17:10.565 --> 00:17:11.885
There's one for scripts.

297
00:17:11.885 --> 00:17:14.080
Theres a client side extension for
security.

298
00:17:14.080 --> 00:17:18.743
For wire for wireless, and if I do,
and there's that one for say,

299
00:17:18.743 --> 00:17:22.004
folder redirection, where's my software?

300
00:17:22.004 --> 00:17:24.187
There's my software
installation policy processor.

301
00:17:24.187 --> 00:17:28.346
So if I wanted to, I could come in
here and I could enable it, and

302
00:17:28.346 --> 00:17:32.130
I could say allow processing,
even if it's a slow link.

303
00:17:32.130 --> 00:17:33.187
All right?

304
00:17:33.187 --> 00:17:36.600
Process even if the group
policy objects haven't changed.

305
00:17:36.600 --> 00:17:39.932
So when it comes to the CSEs,
I really got two things I can modify.

306
00:17:39.932 --> 00:17:43.895
I can change what a slow link is or
I can change whether or

307
00:17:43.895 --> 00:17:49.339
not it runs when a slow link is detected,
depending on which way I wanna go.

308
00:17:49.339 --> 00:17:53.464
So client side extensions, one for
each major category of settings.

309
00:17:53.464 --> 00:17:57.608
There's a couple of them that will
not fire if a slow link is detected.

310
00:17:57.608 --> 00:18:00.352
We can change what a slow link is, or

311
00:18:00.352 --> 00:18:04.841
we can force them to fire,
even if a slow link is detected.

312
00:18:04.841 --> 00:18:09.594
All right, let's see, Wes,
what else do I need to talk about?

313
00:18:09.594 --> 00:18:13.473
I'm trying to think if I, we've covered
a lot of information over these last

314
00:18:13.473 --> 00:18:16.113
few episodes dealing with
scoping those policies.

315
00:18:16.113 --> 00:18:18.428
And there is a little more, but

316
00:18:18.428 --> 00:18:22.981
I can't think of anything else
that we need to hit right now.

317
00:18:22.981 --> 00:18:23.489
>> All right.

318
00:18:23.489 --> 00:18:24.554
Well, very good.

319
00:18:24.554 --> 00:18:26.353
And guys, if any of this information,

320
00:18:26.353 --> 00:18:29.856
as we're mentioning some of these
other parts, you say, well, you know?

00:18:29.856 --> 00:18:30.921
I didn't get to see those parts.

00:18:30.921 --> 00:18:33.562
Well, go back and watch them again and

00:18:33.562 --> 00:18:36.950
And any of these,
maybe the terminology, as well,

324
00:18:36.950 --> 00:18:39.881
might be something that
might be confusing.

325
00:18:39.881 --> 00:18:42.859
Go back and
watch some of those earlier episodes, but

326
00:18:42.859 --> 00:18:45.651
looks like we've come to
the end of this episode.

327
00:18:45.651 --> 00:18:51.665
So we're gonna go ahead, and we're gonna
take the time to sign out here at ITProTV.

00:18:51.665 --> 00:18:53.270

00:18:53.270 --> 00:18:54.042

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Wes will discuss how to filter Group Policy Objects(GPOs) to a specific set of users, groups or computers. They look at security filtering inside of a Windows domain through the Group Policy Management Console. They will demonstrate how to apply a GPO to a specific set attributes on a Windows domain-based computer with Windows Management Instrumentation.
episodes.title: Filtering Group Policy

episodes.description: With all the configurations that you can do with Group Policy Objects whether it be configuring, edit, apply or link to a GPOs we need a way to determine what settings are applying. In this episode Mike and Wes demonstrate how to determine settings through a concept Resultant Set of Policy(RSoP). They look at the utilities to determine RSoP like GPResults in Windows Command Prompt or the Group Policy Results Wizard in Windows Server 2012 R2. They talk about how to determine the "what if" scenarios for GPO application before implementing those settings in a production environment through the Group Policy Modeling Wizard.

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Wes discuss some of the techniques you can use to maintain Group Policy inside of a Windows Active Directory domain. They are going to demonstrate how to backup the Group Policies for the purposes of system maintenance and restoration. They talk about how to manage the Group Policy backups to make it easier to restore those Group Policies. They will show you how to restore the Group Policy inside of the Group Policy Management Console.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike take a look at how administrators can control the user desktop environment using Active Directory Group Policy. Using Folder Redirection as an example, they show how admins can change where users My Document Folder can be redirected to a network location.  Also using the need to map to network drive, Mike demonstrates how to create a script to do that will run as a startup script. Mike also indicates with Windows 8.1 there is a default delay of 5 minutes for scripts to run and shows how to reduce that delay.

00:31:26.060 --> 00:31:28.510
So what I'm going to do,
is I'm going to close this policy.

608
00:31:28.510 --> 00:31:32.990
The setting is actually a computer
setting that controls that delay.

609
00:31:32.990 --> 00:31:38.350
And so I, this policy was linked to the OU
where the developers user accounts are.

610
00:31:38.350 --> 00:31:40.670
Those were your user settings,
and that's fine.

611
00:31:40.670 --> 00:31:44.480
But to affect that delay I need to go to
the OU where the computers are located.

612
00:31:44.480 --> 00:31:46.510
Because it's a computer setting.

613
00:31:46.510 --> 00:31:50.780
So I'm going to go up to my clients OU,
and I'll do this for all my clients.

614
00:31:50.780 --> 00:31:54.201
And so I'm gonna right-click there and
choose Create a GPO and link it here.

615
00:31:54.201 --> 00:32:01.641
And I'll call it
Remove Logon Script Delay.

616
00:32:01.641 --> 00:32:03.581
And I'll click Okay.

617
00:32:03.581 --> 00:32:07.001
And then I am gonna edit that policy.

618
00:32:07.001 --> 00:32:12.997
And that setting we're looking for
is gonna be under Computer Configuration,

619
00:32:12.997 --> 00:32:16.131
Policies, Administrative Templates,

620
00:32:16.131 --> 00:32:20.840
System, Group Policies,
buried way down in there.

621
00:32:20.840 --> 00:32:26.230
And then there is a setting called
Configure Logon Script Delay.

622
00:32:26.230 --> 00:32:29.696
And all I have to do is
choose to turn that on, and

623
00:32:29.696 --> 00:32:34.140
then I can change that to say,
a 0, if I want no delay at all.

624
00:32:34.140 --> 00:32:37.012
Or like I said, it's anything,
I think they'll give you up to,

625
00:32:37.012 --> 00:32:39.589
this is done in minutes,
and the max would be 1,000.

626
00:32:39.589 --> 00:32:42.070
I don't know why you'd want
to delay it 1000 minutes.

627
00:32:42.070 --> 00:32:44.300
But I just wanted you
guys to be aware of this,

628
00:32:44.300 --> 00:32:46.970
because you might have,
in your environment you might have

629
00:32:46.970 --> 00:32:50.860
several log on scripts that you rely
on to setup that user environment.

630
00:32:50.860 --> 00:32:54.720
And all of a sudden you upgrade to Windows
8.1, and your log on scripts seem to fail,

631
00:32:54.720 --> 00:32:57.420
but if you wait long enough
they will kick in, but

632
00:32:57.420 --> 00:32:59.270
maybe I don't want that wait, right?

633
00:32:59.270 --> 00:33:00.290
So that's what this is for.

634
00:33:00.290 --> 00:33:03.740
So I click OK, and now that's turned on.

635
00:33:03.740 --> 00:33:07.415
There should no longer be a delay,
so we'll go restart that machine.

636
00:33:07.415 --> 00:33:10.277
It is a computer setting, so

637
00:33:10.277 --> 00:33:15.060
I do have to Restart,
to get that guy to kick in.

638
00:33:15.060 --> 00:33:18.490
I think what you were saying earlier,
you might have I know several environments

639
00:33:18.490 --> 00:33:21.980
where they've got lots of scripts that
they run to set up that user environment.

640
00:33:21.980 --> 00:33:25.020
And all of a sudden they upgrade it,
and things seem to be broke.

641
00:33:25.020 --> 00:33:26.990
They got users calling up,
where's my map drives?

642
00:33:26.990 --> 00:33:27.780
Where's my printers?

643
00:33:27.780 --> 00:33:28.340
Where's my?

644
00:33:28.340 --> 00:33:30.535
They can't connect to a file server,

645
00:33:30.535 --> 00:33:33.540
cuz you've got an IP seg policy,
that's supposed to be kicking in.

646
00:33:34.850 --> 00:33:37.220
And if you'd wait long enough,
it would actually work.

647
00:33:37.220 --> 00:33:38.842
But users aren't gonna wait that long.

648
00:33:38.842 --> 00:33:41.430
They're gonna see that it's not working,
and within the first 30 seconds,

649
00:33:41.430 --> 00:33:43.410
they're going to call the help desk.

650
00:33:43.410 --> 00:33:45.720
So I'm not a huge fan of that delay.

651
00:33:45.720 --> 00:33:49.280
But If you're having delayed log on times,

652
00:33:49.280 --> 00:33:52.230
because of the scripts,
maybe that delay is right for you.

653
00:33:52.230 --> 00:33:56.350
So we'll go ahead and
log in as Rob here, and see what we get.

654
00:33:58.400 --> 00:34:02.370
So we should, again, no delay, that means
that script should execute immediately

655
00:34:02.370 --> 00:34:06.580
instead of waiting five minutes,
we'll flip over to File Explorer.

656
00:34:08.040 --> 00:34:13.590
And, sure enough, there is my mapped drive
for that data drive, on that file server.

657
00:34:13.590 --> 00:34:16.200
So again,
cool things you can do with logon scripts.

658
00:34:16.200 --> 00:34:20.365
You can run things when you get the logon
scripts, and you got log off scripts.

659
00:34:20.365 --> 00:34:23.405
Maybe when they log off,
I wanna clean up all their temp files.

660
00:34:23.405 --> 00:34:27.025
Great thing to do on public computers,
where I've got shared access.

661
00:34:27.025 --> 00:34:30.365
I don't want the next person that sits
down at that machine at my kiosk,

662
00:34:30.365 --> 00:34:34.535
to see the previous person's Internet
history or things like that.

663
00:34:34.535 --> 00:34:38.215
So, maybe every time somebody logs off,
I wanna clean up temp files.

664
00:34:38.215 --> 00:34:40.015
You got start up and shut down scripts.

665
00:34:40.015 --> 00:34:42.920
When the computer starts up,
when the computer shuts down.

666
00:34:42.920 --> 00:34:47.940
Just keep in mind that with Windows if,
one, copy the scripts into the GPO first,

667
00:34:47.940 --> 00:34:51.100
otherwise they won't be able to
retrieve the script to run it.

668
00:34:51.100 --> 00:34:53.608
And two, don't forget about that delay.

669
00:34:53.608 --> 00:34:57.320
If you're okay with a five minute delay,
that's fine, but you can do away with it,

670
00:34:57.320 --> 00:35:00.130
there's that setting under
the Computer Configuration

671
00:35:00.130 --> 00:35:03.310
that can remove that delay and
have those scripts executed immediately.

672
00:35:03.310 --> 00:35:07.790
>> Now Mike, you know that clearly setting
that up actually seems like a great idea

673
00:35:07.790 --> 00:35:09.460
for us to be able to run those scripts.

674
00:35:09.460 --> 00:35:12.200
The thing that Mike showed you right
away is something that he caught,

675
00:35:12.200 --> 00:35:14.690
which is something I normally don't catch,
is I put

676
00:35:14.690 --> 00:35:17.310
the computer setting into the user's
>> [LAUGH]

677
00:35:17.310 --> 00:35:19.490
>> Setting side instead, or

678
00:35:19.490 --> 00:35:22.320
into the GPO,
which doesn't have that computer account.

679
00:35:22.320 --> 00:35:24.630
And when stuff like that happens,
I know it doesn't run.

680
00:35:24.630 --> 00:35:26.780
I've done that before with just
terminal servers wondering,

681
00:35:26.780 --> 00:35:30.060
why in the world this isn't actually
working, and its because I had set it for

682
00:35:30.060 --> 00:35:33.120
just that user where I'd get the OU for
the users.

683
00:35:33.120 --> 00:35:36.320
>> Yeah it's a great one,
Ronnie,it's an easy mistake.

684
00:35:36.320 --> 00:35:41.340
I do it myself, you might be editing this
policy and you put that script in there,

685
00:35:41.340 --> 00:35:44.110
you think, oh well I need that
script to run immediately.

686
00:35:44.110 --> 00:35:47.790
So you just go up to the computer half,
and you configure that setting.

687
00:35:47.790 --> 00:35:50.897
The problem is the computer account,
isn't in that OU, right.

688
00:35:50.897 --> 00:35:55.230
So you use separate policies linked to
the computers OU, and you're good to go.

689
00:35:55.230 --> 00:35:56.270
>> Excellent Mike.

690
00:35:56.270 --> 00:36:00.960
That's a lot of great ways to actually
help us use the policies that we have

691
00:36:00.960 --> 00:36:05.480
there, inside of Group Policy,
to effectively affect the user, right?

692
00:36:05.480 --> 00:36:08.705
By being able to do this we can
control what the user actually does,

693
00:36:08.705 --> 00:36:11.730
a lot of times even without
them needing to know about it.

694
00:36:11.730 --> 00:36:14.620
It makes the uniformity for
all of our users.

695
00:36:14.620 --> 00:36:17.710
It gives us the ability to set
the controls that we need in place,

696
00:36:17.710 --> 00:36:20.960
by putting these types of scripts
that Mike was talking about, right?

697
00:36:20.960 --> 00:36:24.700
We actually are now able to control
when they're actually going to run, and

698
00:36:24.700 --> 00:36:27.570
instead of depending on every
individual user to go, please,

699
00:36:27.570 --> 00:36:29.090
did you make sure you ran that?

700
00:36:29.090 --> 00:36:29.660
Oh, I forgot.

701
00:36:29.660 --> 00:36:32.960
And then they have to run it and they're
like when was I supposed to run that?

702
00:36:32.960 --> 00:36:34.420
And you just go never mind.

703
00:36:34.420 --> 00:36:37.475
Setting new script up helps us to
be able to automate even that,

704
00:36:37.475 --> 00:36:41.650
a little bit more and gives us much
better control by using Group Policy.

705
00:36:41.650 --> 00:36:44.350
So thank you again, Mike, for
that demonstration, great and

706
00:36:44.350 --> 00:36:46.140
effective demonstration to help us.

707
00:36:46.140 --> 00:36:49.800
Thank you, also, for
watching us here on ITProTV.

708
00:36:49.800 --> 00:36:51.110
Signing off I'm Ronnie Wong.

709
00:36:51.110 --> 00:36:52.150
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

710
00:36:52.150 --> 00:36:53.935
>> And we'll see you next time.

711
00:36:53.935 --> 00:36:54.975
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike guide us through the creating an audit policy. They use the example of object access and account logon events to show where the audits will take place and why we would want to create an audit policy. Mike demonstrates the two step process in creating an object access audit to work. Using the event viewer, we see the results of the audit.
episodes.title: Auditing Policies
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.245 --> 00:00:15.008
Welcome to another great
episode here on ITProTv.

3
00:00:15.008 --> 00:00:16.690
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

4
00:00:16.690 --> 00:00:19.310
And today we're gonna be
working with group policy.

5
00:00:19.310 --> 00:00:23.330
We're specifically gonna be looking at
creating audit policies to help us out.

6
00:00:23.330 --> 00:00:25.240
We really do need to
track things like well,

7
00:00:25.240 --> 00:00:28.400
account audit events that
we have to be able to do.

8
00:00:28.400 --> 00:00:30.980
And who better to help us than Mr.
Mike Rodrick.

9
00:00:30.980 --> 00:00:34.480
Mike, when we start talking about creating
an audit policy, let's go ahead and

10
00:00:34.480 --> 00:00:38.060
answer the question, why do I really
care about auditing these things?

11
00:00:38.060 --> 00:00:40.350
And what else do we need
to know about them?

12
00:00:40.350 --> 00:00:44.040
>> Well probably a lot, but
the very basic question is a great one.

13
00:00:44.040 --> 00:00:45.940
Why do we have to audit, why do we care?

14
00:00:45.940 --> 00:00:48.340
Well, a couple of reasons, right.

15
00:00:48.340 --> 00:00:52.850
One it could be because simply as
an organization, I need to track things.

16
00:00:52.850 --> 00:00:55.960
I need to know who's
making those new files?

17
00:00:55.960 --> 00:00:58.540
Who's modifying those existing files?

18
00:00:58.540 --> 00:01:00.600
Who's making new accounts
in active directory?

19
00:01:00.600 --> 00:01:03.112
Who's making changes to group policies,
right?

20
00:01:03.112 --> 00:01:05.670
Those kinda things we can track that,
we can find out.

21
00:01:05.670 --> 00:01:07.667
I wanna come in a go,
hey there's a new policy here.

22
00:01:07.667 --> 00:01:11.450
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's blocking everybody from x, y, z.

23
00:01:11.450 --> 00:01:12.480
Where the heck did it come from?

24
00:01:12.480 --> 00:01:13.240
Who made it?
Right?

25
00:01:13.240 --> 00:01:15.160
Or why is this policy not working?

26
00:01:15.160 --> 00:01:18.890
Or somebody changed something,
or who deleted Ronie's account?

27
00:01:18.890 --> 00:01:20.530
Right.
Ronnie comes into work one day

28
00:01:20.530 --> 00:01:21.980
can't log in to do some research.

29
00:01:21.980 --> 00:01:23.460
And his account's gone.

30
00:01:23.460 --> 00:01:25.000
Where the heck did it go?

31
00:01:25.000 --> 00:01:25.900
Who did it?

32
00:01:25.900 --> 00:01:27.250
I need to track those kinda things.

33
00:01:27.250 --> 00:01:28.950
Right?
A logon events.

34
00:01:28.950 --> 00:01:31.710
I need to be able to track
when people are logging on or

35
00:01:31.710 --> 00:01:35.950
those strange log on attempts that
are occurring 2 o'clock in the morning,

36
00:01:35.950 --> 00:01:37.940
when nobody's supposed
to be in the building.

37
00:01:37.940 --> 00:01:39.460
I wanna be able to track that kinda stuff.

38
00:01:39.460 --> 00:01:42.120
That's exactly what we do
with our audit policies.

39
00:01:42.120 --> 00:01:45.060
Second is it might be required, right?

40
00:01:45.060 --> 00:01:48.910
If you're a company or an organization
that falls under any of those

41
00:01:48.910 --> 00:01:51.430
governmental regulations or
industry regulations,

42
00:01:51.430 --> 00:01:55.740
like HIPAA, or Sarbanes Oxley, or
anything like that, you have to track.

43
00:01:55.740 --> 00:01:58.490
There's a governmental
regulation that says

44
00:01:58.490 --> 00:02:02.140
you need to be able to prove who access
these records, when they were changed,

45
00:02:02.140 --> 00:02:04.810
why they were changed,
you know all that stuff.

46
00:02:04.810 --> 00:02:08.590
It could be just that your organization
wants to do it just because they wanna

47
00:02:08.590 --> 00:02:12.270
keep track, or it could be you've got
a requirement that you could be audited

48
00:02:12.270 --> 00:02:15.710
as an organization and you've gotta
produce all of this information.

49
00:02:15.710 --> 00:02:20.540
You've gotta produce a track record of how
those patient records were kept safe and

50
00:02:20.540 --> 00:02:25.350
that nobody accessed them without
authorization and things like that.

51
00:02:25.350 --> 00:02:29.210
So lots of reasons in
the end that we wanna audit.

52
00:02:29.210 --> 00:02:31.980
>> So when we talk about the audit
policies that we're gonna be taking a look

53
00:02:31.980 --> 00:02:36.680
at today it really is about the idea of
accessing maybe what you're talking about,

54
00:02:36.680 --> 00:02:39.230
a particular file and
changing or permissions.

55
00:02:39.230 --> 00:02:43.730
As well as the account log on or
just the individual log on as well.

56
00:02:43.730 --> 00:02:44.990
And those are great examples for

57
00:02:44.990 --> 00:02:47.420
us because that's what we're usually
what we're really looking for.

58
00:02:47.420 --> 00:02:49.800
Did somebody access something
they weren't suppose to?

59
00:02:49.800 --> 00:02:52.670
Is somebody actually logging in let's
say at times that they're also not

60
00:02:52.670 --> 00:02:53.770
suppose as well.

61
00:02:53.770 --> 00:02:56.710
By creating these things,
we really begin to set this in place.

62
00:02:56.710 --> 00:03:01.310
We're starting to see the power of a group
policy, especially in helping us to

63
00:03:01.310 --> 00:03:05.010
identify who's doing it,
at what particular point in time, and

64
00:03:05.010 --> 00:03:08.250
maybe in how often we're actually starting
to see this stuff, which may actually

65
00:03:08.250 --> 00:03:10.930
indicate, well even other types
of attacks that may be going on.

66
00:03:10.930 --> 00:03:11.450
>> Yeah.
>> So Mike,

67
00:03:11.450 --> 00:03:13.820
where do we need to begin when we
start taking a look at these policies.

68
00:03:13.820 --> 00:03:16.040
>> We're gonna start here
looking at our group policies.

69
00:03:16.040 --> 00:03:17.940
First thing I wanna show you
is the different categories.

70
00:03:17.940 --> 00:03:20.660
And as Ronnie said,
now there's a lot of different things,

71
00:03:20.660 --> 00:03:22.390
we're gonna focus on a couple of them.

72
00:03:22.390 --> 00:03:26.890
Mainly because they're very common ones
that most organizations wanna implement

73
00:03:26.890 --> 00:03:28.580
as basic auditing.

74
00:03:28.580 --> 00:03:31.700
And two they all work
pretty much the same,

75
00:03:31.700 --> 00:03:35.960
you just have to figure out what
category it is that you wanna work with.

76
00:03:35.960 --> 00:03:37.350
So let me show you what I mean here.

77
00:03:37.350 --> 00:03:41.740
I'm gonna open up my
Group Policy Management console, and

78
00:03:41.740 --> 00:03:45.800
I'm gonna grab any policy for right now.

79
00:03:45.800 --> 00:03:50.580
Just so we can look at the these settings,
and then we'll work our way from there.

80
00:03:50.580 --> 00:03:53.530
So here I've right clicked on that policy,
and I chose Edit.

81
00:03:53.530 --> 00:03:57.367
And my settings are gonna be under
the Computer Configuration Policies.

82
00:03:57.367 --> 00:04:00.056
Windows Settings.

83
00:04:00.056 --> 00:04:02.924
Security Settings.

84
00:04:02.924 --> 00:04:04.900
Local policy.

85
00:04:04.900 --> 00:04:06.810
And then audit policy.

86
00:04:06.810 --> 00:04:07.560
All right.

87
00:04:07.560 --> 00:04:10.095
These nine, I think there is
nine if I remember correctly.

88
00:04:10.095 --> 00:04:15.015
Yeah, these nine categories are the
original audit categories that we've had

89
00:04:15.015 --> 00:04:16.755
all the way back to Windows Server 2000,

90
00:04:16.755 --> 00:04:20.395
and most of them are pretty
straightforward.

91
00:04:20.395 --> 00:04:25.200
The account log on and the log on
events can be a little bit confusing.

92
00:04:25.200 --> 00:04:27.800
I'll go back and
hit those in just a second.

93
00:04:27.800 --> 00:04:29.130
Account management.

94
00:04:29.130 --> 00:04:33.250
I need to know when somebody's deleting
a user account, active directory.

95
00:04:33.250 --> 00:04:35.960
Or changing a password or
updating a value.

96
00:04:35.960 --> 00:04:37.430
You an attribute.

97
00:04:37.430 --> 00:04:40.440
Directory service access,
again maybe they're getting in there and

98
00:04:40.440 --> 00:04:42.560
making new OUs or creating new groups.

99
00:04:42.560 --> 00:04:44.110
So anything in Active Directory.

100
00:04:45.570 --> 00:04:49.550
Object access would be things
like files and folders.

101
00:04:49.550 --> 00:04:51.030
Policy change.

102
00:04:51.030 --> 00:04:54.300
Who's making changes to the policies
themselves, or creating new ones, or

103
00:04:54.300 --> 00:04:55.065
unlinking them?

104
00:04:55.065 --> 00:04:55.645
Right?

105
00:04:55.645 --> 00:05:00.885
Somebody might be, if they've gained
access somehow to group policy and

106
00:05:00.885 --> 00:05:05.447
they've unlinked the policy cuz
they didn't like what it did,

107
00:05:05.447 --> 00:05:09.210
right or
they've made a change to a policy.

108
00:05:09.210 --> 00:05:14.084
Privilege use, well if you've ever
used a right that was assigned to

109
00:05:14.084 --> 00:05:18.788
you like being able to change
the system time, or reboot a server,

110
00:05:18.788 --> 00:05:24.101
audit process tracking, this one is
a lot of times useful for developers.

111
00:05:24.101 --> 00:05:29.035
Cuz I can track what a process reaches out
and hits other resources like reaching out

112
00:05:29.035 --> 00:05:34.200
and grabbing, I don't know, a reference to
a database maybe or something like that.

113
00:05:34.200 --> 00:05:38.490
And then system events, things that
are occurring on that system itself.

114
00:05:38.490 --> 00:05:42.488
So these are the main categories or the
ones, like I said, that we've always had.

115
00:05:42.488 --> 00:05:48.276
But they have added a few more and
when I say a few I mean like 53.

116
00:05:48.276 --> 00:05:51.920
[LAUGH] So if I scroll down a little
bit further I can see this advanced

117
00:05:51.920 --> 00:05:52.900
audit policy node.

118
00:05:52.900 --> 00:05:56.530
Now I'll make it that a little wider so
we can see it a little easier.

119
00:05:56.530 --> 00:05:59.860
I'll expand that out and

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike take a look at controlling AD Clients. Using IE settings, Windows Updates, and Windows Firewall. They demonstrate centralized control over user settings so that users are disabled from configuring settings. This is a great option when we do not want users to change settings that may violate policies we have in place. They demonstrate where to locate the settings and how they apply.
episodes.title: Configuring Clients

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike show us how to use AD Group Policy to control applications within our domains. The use of these policies are necessary to help stop unauthorized applications from being installed on users desktops, according to the guys. They take a look at differences between Software Restriction Policies and AppLocker. Mike also demonstrates the flexibility of Applocker through all the settings available to restrict applications beyond the hash and location values.

Notepad.

00:21:26.580 --> 00:21:30.066

00:21:30.066 --> 00:21:34.867

00:21:34.867 --> 00:21:39.330

00:21:39.330 --> 00:21:39.920
I don't think I've ever-

00:21:39.920 --> 00:21:41.670
>> Seen it kick in on the first try.

00:21:42.860 --> 00:21:46.130

00:21:46.130 --> 00:21:48.550
eventually it will kick in.

00:21:48.550 --> 00:21:51.280
If I'm gonna try, let's just Restart
it and try it one more time,

00:21:51.280 --> 00:21:55.970
and then I'll show you a couple of trouble

00:21:55.970 --> 00:21:58.380
more than likely it's just a time thing.

00:21:58.380 --> 00:22:01.280
It's gonna take a little bit
before that policy kicks in,

421
00:22:01.280 --> 00:22:03.390
I don't know what it is about it.

422
00:22:03.390 --> 00:22:05.030
It is slow right, but
the policies gonna be there.

00:22:05.030 --> 00:22:08.690
I'm gonna show you where
the policies being applied.

00:22:08.690 --> 00:22:12.620
It's something to do with that
application identity service and

00:22:12.620 --> 00:22:16.885
how long it takes to get up and
running and start scanning applications.

00:22:16.885 --> 00:22:17.730
cuz what it's supposed to do,

00:22:17.730 --> 00:22:21.040
is every time you launch
an application that identity service,

428
00:22:21.040 --> 00:22:24.930
that application identity service looks
at it, sees if it's on that list.

429
00:22:24.930 --> 00:22:27.674
And for some reason it takes
it's sweet time doing that.

430
00:22:27.674 --> 00:22:31.110
>> [LAUGH]
>> So we'll login as Rob again.

431
00:22:31.110 --> 00:22:34.370
And we'll try it one more time.

432
00:22:34.370 --> 00:22:36.040
Keep your fingers crossed.

433
00:22:40.390 --> 00:22:44.060
We'll go to Notepad, and
sure enough there it goes.

434
00:22:44.060 --> 00:22:45.580
So troubleshooting this.

435
00:22:46.970 --> 00:22:49.080
The first thing I'm gonna do,
I'm gonna log off here and

436
00:22:49.080 --> 00:22:51.020
sign back in as the local admin.

00:22:51.020 --> 00:22:53.160
As far as the group policy side goes,

438
00:22:53.160 --> 00:22:56.600
I wanna make sure that that policy
is linked to the proper OU.
