00:22:56.600 --> 00:23:00.380
It's linked to the clients computer's OU
which is where that client machine is so

440
00:23:00.380 --> 00:23:02.340
we're good to go there.

441
00:23:02.340 --> 00:23:05.870
As far as the setting goes, let's make
sure I clicked Deny and not Allow.

442
00:23:05.870 --> 00:23:10.575
These are just some of the things
that you would wanna check.

443
00:23:10.575 --> 00:23:15.830
So let's see here,
self restriction policies,

444
00:23:15.830 --> 00:23:17.560
I didn't actually create any of those.

445
00:23:19.060 --> 00:23:20.750
Application Control Policies.

446
00:23:20.750 --> 00:23:22.140
There's my default rules.

447
00:23:22.140 --> 00:23:23.860
Here's my Executables.

448
00:23:23.860 --> 00:23:26.221
In force is set to true, so
I know I checked that little check mark,

449
00:23:26.221 --> 00:23:26.778
that's good.

450
00:23:26.778 --> 00:23:30.410
Deny everyone, notepad.exe.

451
00:23:31.970 --> 00:23:36.640
No exceptions, so I know that I set
up my policy correctly doing it.

452
00:23:36.640 --> 00:23:41.990
So we'll jump back up out here,
we'll flip back over to client.

453
00:23:41.990 --> 00:23:44.912
The next thing I would do is check and

454
00:23:44.912 --> 00:23:49.274
see if that policy is even, [INAUDIBLE]
>> [LAUGH]

455
00:23:49.274 --> 00:23:54.557
>> Silly me, let me sign out.

456
00:23:54.557 --> 00:23:58.562
And we'll Log in as the administrator,
so we can do some troubleshooting.

457
00:24:02.600 --> 00:24:04.601
So I wanna do a GPresult, right?

458
00:24:04.601 --> 00:24:07.920
So make sure that the Group Policy
is actually being applied.

459
00:24:07.920 --> 00:24:09.560
So I'll open up that command prompt.

460
00:24:13.210 --> 00:24:13.870
Do a little gpresult r.

461
00:24:13.870 --> 00:24:20.580
And we'll get this get play along.

462
00:24:20.580 --> 00:24:24.710
I know the computer have,
I see my software restriction.

463
00:24:24.710 --> 00:24:25.740
Is that the one that I created?

464
00:24:25.740 --> 00:24:26.780
Let's double check that.

465
00:24:26.780 --> 00:24:28.830
Yeah, software restriction.

466
00:24:28.830 --> 00:24:29.770
So that one is there.

467
00:24:29.770 --> 00:24:32.803
So, that's good.
The next thing I'm gonna wanna check would

468
00:24:32.803 --> 00:24:36.110
be to make sure that service
is actually running.

469
00:24:38.310 --> 00:24:39.050
Whoops.

470
00:24:39.050 --> 00:24:39.550
That's not how you spell it.

471
00:24:43.556 --> 00:24:46.083
So we'll go check on that
application identity, and

472
00:24:46.083 --> 00:24:48.563
I can see that it is set to
startup type is automatic.

473
00:24:48.563 --> 00:24:51.410
Which was in that same policy, right.

474
00:24:51.410 --> 00:24:53.430
So you know that policy's being applied.

475
00:24:53.430 --> 00:24:56.183
See what I'm saying?
So as you're troubleshooting you can kinda

476
00:24:56.183 --> 00:24:59.750
figure that out, but we'll go ahead and
close that and that.

477
00:24:59.750 --> 00:25:05.290
Now I can't test Notepad because I'm
an administrator and we get a free pass.

478
00:25:05.290 --> 00:25:05.810
So I need to log off.

479
00:25:05.810 --> 00:25:09.480
In fact I'm just gonna go ahead and
restart this machine.

480
00:25:10.860 --> 00:25:15.240
All right, and we'll give it a minute and
we'll let that application identity

481
00:25:15.240 --> 00:25:19.549
service launch up, get started and
make sure it's running here.

482
00:25:20.770 --> 00:25:22.520
All right, so
Ronnie while we're waiting for that,

483
00:25:22.520 --> 00:25:26.410
I guess the other thing I wanna talk
about is the mixed environments again.

484
00:25:26.410 --> 00:25:30.670
One of the things you have to be aware
of is we can use both, all right?

485
00:25:30.670 --> 00:25:34.430
If I've got Windows 8 clients as
well as Windows XP clients, and

486
00:25:34.430 --> 00:25:37.575
I wanna restrict software,
I'm gonna need to use both.

487
00:25:37.575 --> 00:25:41.690
AppLocker for those modern operating
systems, software restrictions for

488
00:25:41.690 --> 00:25:43.500
those older operating systems.

489
00:25:43.500 --> 00:25:49.410
What we need to know is that you can't
use both of them in the same GPO.

490
00:25:49.410 --> 00:25:50.890
We can do them in the same domain.

491
00:25:50.890 --> 00:25:52.760
We can have two separate GPO's.

492
00:25:52.760 --> 00:25:54.849
One with the software restriction policy,

493
00:25:54.849 --> 00:25:57.590
one with the AppLocker policy
linked to the same OU.

494
00:25:57.590 --> 00:26:01.630
Because in that OU, I've got Windows XP
class as well as Windows 8 class.

495
00:26:01.630 --> 00:26:05.170
I just can't put the settings
in the same GPO, right?

496
00:26:05.170 --> 00:26:09.560
if you put both Software Restrictions and
AppLocker settings

497
00:26:09.560 --> 00:26:13.340
in the same GPO then it's gonna ignore
the Software Restriction Policies and

498
00:26:13.340 --> 00:26:18.250
only apply the AppLocker policies which
means your XP machines won't work,

499
00:26:18.250 --> 00:26:21.150
they will be able to run
the applications not gonna block them.

500
00:26:21.150 --> 00:26:24.680
So it's perfectly fine to use them both
and you need to in a mixed environment.

501
00:26:24.680 --> 00:26:26.920
Just don't put them in the same GPO.

502
00:26:26.920 --> 00:26:29.670
Separate GPOs for
software restriction versus Ad Blocker.

503
00:26:29.670 --> 00:26:31.640
All right so we'll see what happens.

504
00:26:31.640 --> 00:26:33.050
We'll log back in as Rob.

505
00:26:35.240 --> 00:26:37.440
And once we get logged in,

506
00:26:37.440 --> 00:26:42.180
we'll keep our fingers crossed and
we'll try to run notepad.

507
00:26:42.180 --> 00:26:46.210
So we'll do a little Start Run,
notepad.exe.

508
00:26:47.390 --> 00:26:48.310
And there we go.

509
00:26:48.310 --> 00:26:50.080
That is AppLocker kicking in.

510
00:26:50.080 --> 00:26:52.650
Your system administrator
has blocked this program.

511
00:26:52.650 --> 00:26:55.830
For more information,
contact your system administrator.

512
00:26:55.830 --> 00:26:59.152
Now one other thing I do
wanna point out here, Ronnie,

513
00:26:59.152 --> 00:27:02.920
if I go over to my Windows 8 Start
screen and I launch Notepad.

514
00:27:04.480 --> 00:27:05.759
All right.

515
00:27:07.370 --> 00:27:11.550
Notice that it flips over to desktop,
but I don't get any message.

516
00:27:11.550 --> 00:27:12.220
I don't like that.

517
00:27:12.220 --> 00:27:13.620
I wish Microsoft would fix that.

518
00:27:13.620 --> 00:27:15.790
If you're listening Microsoft,
[LAUGH] please fix that.

519
00:27:17.040 --> 00:27:21.040
Something gets lost in the transition
from that new start screen

520
00:27:21.040 --> 00:27:22.360
to the old school desktop.

521
00:27:22.360 --> 00:27:24.010
The message disappears.

522
00:27:24.010 --> 00:27:27.540
If I run it from the desktop,
like if I had a shortcut out here.

523
00:27:27.540 --> 00:27:29.350
Or if I just type in notepad.

524
00:27:30.720 --> 00:27:34.870
I see the message just fine.

525
00:27:34.870 --> 00:27:41.210
If I'm over on my start screen and I try
to run Notepad it doesn't let it run.

526
00:27:41.210 --> 00:27:42.530
But I don't get that message.

527
00:27:42.530 --> 00:27:45.890
So the problem I have with that
is my end user's gonna be saying

528
00:27:45.890 --> 00:27:47.440
something's wrong with my machine.

529
00:27:47.440 --> 00:27:49.810
They don't see that message that
they think notepad is broken so

530
00:27:49.810 --> 00:27:53.030
they're gonna call the help desk,
hey how come I can't launch Notepad.

531
00:27:53.030 --> 00:27:55.310
You're not supposed to be able
to launch NotePad, right.

532
00:27:55.310 --> 00:27:58.860
They just don't get that message and
that kinda annoys me, but that is it.

533
00:27:58.860 --> 00:28:01.500
That's how we control those applications.

534
00:28:01.500 --> 00:28:05.730
>> Yeah, now it seems like the key here is
patience, right, more than anything else

535
00:28:05.730 --> 00:28:08.330
is that we have to be patient with
it actually being on a kick in.

536
00:28:08.330 --> 00:28:10.220
Sometimes thing may work right away,

537
00:28:10.220 --> 00:28:13.930
but on this one in particular it looks
like it takes a little bit of time.

538
00:28:13.930 --> 00:28:17.040
So several reboots and
then we're actually ready to go.

539
00:28:17.040 --> 00:28:22.610
So don't, we shouldn't say that you can
expect it to work immediately [LAUGH] but

540
00:28:22.610 --> 00:28:27.380
our experience is that
it takes a bit of time.

541
00:28:27.380 --> 00:28:28.640
>> Yeah.
I think sometimes,

542
00:28:28.640 --> 00:28:31.380
I know I get a little big impatient,
because I went and

543
00:28:31.380 --> 00:28:33.870
created the policy,
I wanna test it right now.

544
00:28:33.870 --> 00:28:38.060
And the reality is, I'll be creating
this policy, deploying it out across my

545
00:28:38.060 --> 00:28:43.610
enterprise and by tomorrow it's gonna be
effectively blocking that application.

546
00:28:43.610 --> 00:28:46.530
Once they log on in the morning,
log off, go to lunch,

547
00:28:46.530 --> 00:28:51.560
log back in, refresh policy a couple
times, normally through the refresh cycle,

548
00:28:51.560 --> 00:28:56.910
it's gonna kick in, it's gonna block note
pad, it just might not do it immediately.

549
00:28:56.910 --> 00:28:59.690
And usually we're okay with that, right.

550
00:28:59.690 --> 00:29:02.750
The only other thing you could do is
like force reboot on all your systems,

551
00:29:02.750 --> 00:29:04.820
try to speed that process up.

552
00:29:04.820 --> 00:29:05.730
>> Excellent.

553
00:29:05.730 --> 00:29:09.340
So in this episode right we took a look
at a couple different ways that we can

554
00:29:09.340 --> 00:29:13.490
control the way that applications are
gonna appear on our end users computer, or

555
00:29:13.490 --> 00:29:15.000
actually not even be able to run.

556
00:29:15.000 --> 00:29:17.980
So we can actually control it using
the software restriction policies

557
00:29:17.980 --> 00:29:21.040
as well as that application control
policy that we call AppLocker.

558
00:29:21.040 --> 00:29:24.540
If you're actually in a mixed environment,
you may actually need to use both so

00:29:24.540 --> 00:29:28.670
do remember that little piece of knowledge

560
00:29:28.670 --> 00:29:32.730
When now all of a sudden one

00:29:32.730 --> 00:29:37.550
your newer machines as well, so you do

562
00:29:37.550 --> 00:29:41.280
Also, remember the idea of
patience is the key here.

563
00:29:41.280 --> 00:29:44.170
Being able to do that is also gonna
take a little bit of time and

564
00:29:44.170 --> 00:29:47.760
trial and whatever works for your
environment, that's what you'll also have.

565
00:29:47.760 --> 00:29:51.550
But with what we talked about in
the AppLocker, amazing flexibility too.

566
00:29:51.550 --> 00:29:52.780
Mike, did you have something?

567
00:29:52.780 --> 00:29:54.590
>> Yeah, the one last thing I
wanna leave you guys with is,

00:29:54.590 --> 00:29:56.170
we could go the other route, right?

569
00:29:56.170 --> 00:29:58.310
We talk about blocking applications.

570
00:29:58.310 --> 00:30:02.600
If I've got a kiosk machine that I really

00:30:02.600 --> 00:30:07.460
I can block everything and then just

00:30:07.460 --> 00:30:11.510
Right, instead of allowing everything and
then trying to block certain applications,

573
00:30:11.510 --> 00:30:12.970
so just keep that in mind.

574
00:30:12.970 --> 00:30:18.120
>> Oh yeah there's another context that
we might also use a application locker

575
00:30:18.120 --> 00:30:20.030
to help us out as well.

00:30:20.030 --> 00:30:21.685
All right.
So that's a great place for

00:30:21.685 --> 00:30:24.385

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike introduce Group Policy Preferences. These preferences help to extend the capabilities of Group Policy and make it easier to manage, according to Mike. They take some time to show where and how to configure the preferences as well. Preferences are effective when we need to set default configurations but also allow for the user to be able to change when necessary.
episodes.title: Group Policy Preferences
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:10.008
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.997 --> 00:00:16.198
Welcome to another great
episode here on IT PRO TV.

3
00:00:16.198 --> 00:00:17.494
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and

4
00:00:17.494 --> 00:00:20.690
today we're gonna be taking a look
at working with group policy.

5
00:00:20.690 --> 00:00:25.690
We're specifically gonna be diving in
to using Group Policy Preferences and

6
00:00:25.690 --> 00:00:28.380
that's what we actually wanna focus in on.

7
00:00:28.380 --> 00:00:31.500
Mike, the very fact is, and here's Mr.
Mike Rogers of course.

8
00:00:31.500 --> 00:00:35.480
Mike, the very fact is, I have policies
and I understand what those policies are.

9
00:00:35.480 --> 00:00:37.910
I also start to see inside of
the Group Policy Management Console,

10
00:00:37.910 --> 00:00:39.390
I have preferences.

11
00:00:39.390 --> 00:00:43.020
But why would I choose to ever use
preferences if I have policies?

12
00:00:43.020 --> 00:00:45.810
>> Couple of reasons, Ronnie, great
question and first of all they're new and

13
00:00:45.810 --> 00:00:47.000
exciting so we want to use them.

14
00:00:47.000 --> 00:00:47.901
>> Nice, nice.

15
00:00:47.901 --> 00:00:49.307
[LAUGH]
>> I kid, I tease,

16
00:00:49.307 --> 00:00:52.859
no but group policy preferences
came about because there

17
00:00:52.859 --> 00:00:56.500
were certain limitations
to group policy settings.

18
00:00:56.500 --> 00:01:00.800
There were some things that we just
couldn't do with a normal GPO.

19
00:01:00.800 --> 00:01:02.410
Before we had these preferences.

20
00:01:02.410 --> 00:01:05.840
The big ones that I remember working with,
Ronnie, were mapping network drives.

21
00:01:05.840 --> 00:01:09.730
There was no easy way to map
a network drive with a GPO so

22
00:01:09.730 --> 00:01:12.180
what we would do as admins
if we would create scripts.

23
00:01:12.180 --> 00:01:16.850
Ether startup scripts or log on scripts so
every time that user would log on

24
00:01:16.850 --> 00:01:20.310
these scripts would execute and
it would map drives in the background.

25
00:01:20.310 --> 00:01:24.950
Which worked fine but that does put
a little bit of a delay on that log on or

26
00:01:24.950 --> 00:01:27.370
like if it can't reach out and
find that drive,

27
00:01:27.370 --> 00:01:30.170
it could have issues about
executing that script.

28
00:01:30.170 --> 00:01:33.760
So it's a little bit cumbersome there.

29
00:01:33.760 --> 00:01:35.100
Printers were another one.

30
00:01:35.100 --> 00:01:38.140
There was no real easy way
to deploy printers out

31
00:01:38.140 --> 00:01:42.070
to my end users via a group policy until

32
00:01:42.070 --> 00:01:45.890
I wanna say 2008 when they started
adding some GPO settings to do that.

33
00:01:45.890 --> 00:01:48.570
So preferences were actually
developed outside of Microsoft.

34
00:01:48.570 --> 00:01:52.690
It was another organization and I should
know this guy's or this company's name and

35
00:01:52.690 --> 00:01:57.870
I can't remember but they developed
these preferences as an add on.

36
00:01:57.870 --> 00:02:00.980
Microsoft liked them so
much that they incorporated them in.

37
00:02:00.980 --> 00:02:04.850
They said let's make those
a standard part of this GPU.

38
00:02:04.850 --> 00:02:08.430
The group policy management console and
group policies themselves and

39
00:02:08.430 --> 00:02:11.830
so we get those now in a GPO.

40
00:02:11.830 --> 00:02:15.670
So we got those preferences as
well as our normal settings.

41
00:02:15.670 --> 00:02:19.500
The other cool thing about preferences
is the filtering capabilities.

42
00:02:19.500 --> 00:02:22.730
What they call item level targeting.

43
00:02:22.730 --> 00:02:24.360
And it's fantastic.

44
00:02:24.360 --> 00:02:27.290
We've learned in here how to
do security filtering, right?

45
00:02:27.290 --> 00:02:29.940
We can go to that scope tab of GPO.

46
00:02:29.940 --> 00:02:33.670
I can remove the authenticated users
group and add in a different group.

47
00:02:33.670 --> 00:02:38.130
So that it only applies to people that
are in that group or I can go to that

48
00:02:38.130 --> 00:02:42.810
delegation tab and click advance and open
up the access control list for a GPO and

49
00:02:42.810 --> 00:02:46.780
I can filter policies there
based on permissions with you,

50
00:02:46.780 --> 00:02:50.070
if I deny you the permission to
apply your policy for example.

51
00:02:50.070 --> 00:02:53.290
Then it won't apply to you even
if it's scoped to know you

52
00:02:53.290 --> 00:02:55.960
that you're user account or
computer account is in.

53

00:28:40.070 --> 00:28:43.360
And think I can still do my item
level targeting with these things,

504
00:28:43.360 --> 00:28:49.150
I can still control which machine based on
like operating system or what have you.

505
00:28:49.150 --> 00:28:49.890
With those settings.

506
00:28:49.890 --> 00:28:53.500
So in the end,
preferences are really neat.

507
00:28:53.500 --> 00:28:56.930
They extend the functionality
of group policy objects

508
00:28:56.930 --> 00:28:58.920
to do things that we couldn't do before.

509
00:28:58.920 --> 00:29:02.550
And they're just very easy to work with,
I don't have that WQL to learn.

510
00:29:02.550 --> 00:29:04.490
I don't have to worry
about security filtering,

511
00:29:04.490 --> 00:29:07.690
it's all wizard, drop-down list based.

512
00:29:07.690 --> 00:29:08.560
Pretty darn cool.

513
00:29:08.560 --> 00:29:09.980
>> It really is, Mike.

514
00:29:09.980 --> 00:29:13.710
Being though that you usually use policies
are really one of the things that allow us

515
00:29:13.710 --> 00:29:17.760
to look like we're setting things in place
to make it more easy for our end users.

516
00:29:17.760 --> 00:29:20.430
That same time it gives
them also the flexibility

517
00:29:20.430 --> 00:29:22.600
to be able to change them if they need to.

518
00:29:22.600 --> 00:29:26.310
So, unlike a policy in which they can't
change anything with the preferences.

519
00:29:26.310 --> 00:29:29.600
They can go ahead and say look,
hey that's not my default printer, and

520
00:29:29.600 --> 00:29:30.570
actually be able to change that.

521
00:29:30.570 --> 00:29:33.060
And a lot of times they can do that
with the other settings as well.

522
00:29:33.060 --> 00:29:35.980
So it makes it nice and
easy for us as administrators,

523
00:29:35.980 --> 00:29:39.310
it makes it easy to let the users
know that we've got it set, but

524
00:29:39.310 --> 00:29:42.070
then if they do need to change
it they can change it also.

525
00:29:42.070 --> 00:29:44.130
Mike, as far as policies and

526
00:29:44.130 --> 00:29:47.630
preferences combined together,
they shouldn't conflict with each other.

527
00:29:47.630 --> 00:29:48.750
Everything should work fine, right?

528
00:29:48.750 --> 00:29:51.032
>> Yeah, absolutely, never conflict.

529
00:29:51.032 --> 00:29:54.460
[LAUGH] Now, same thing would apply
though if we've got policies or

530
00:29:54.460 --> 00:29:57.260
preference settings, you know,
linked to different levels.

531
00:29:57.260 --> 00:30:00.130
You still have that same inheritance and

532
00:30:00.130 --> 00:30:04.230
precedence to deal with, so
if you've got a later policy can override,

533
00:30:04.230 --> 00:30:08.232
a previously applied policy so
in the end it all works the same.

534
00:30:08.232 --> 00:30:10.890
>> Excellent, all right,
that's a great place for us go for and

535
00:30:10.890 --> 00:30:12.290
end this episode, then.

536
00:30:12.290 --> 00:30:14.710
Signing off for ITProTV I'm Ronnie Wong.

537
00:30:14.710 --> 00:30:15.560
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

538
00:30:15.560 --> 00:30:16.527
>> And we'll see you next time.

539
00:30:16.527 --> 00:30:22.580
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike take a look at deploying software through Group Policy.  They emphasize the fact that this only really works with .MSI files. Within the GPMC, the guys take a look at the differences between assigning and publishing the software installation between user configurations and computer configurations as well.  Then they demonstrate the assigning of software installation through the user setting.
episodes.title: Security Templates
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.004 --> 00:00:10.004
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:13.005 --> 00:00:15.780
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.780 --> 00:00:19.140
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and
today we're taking that Working

4
00:00:19.140 --> 00:00:22.630
with Group Policy, when we talk
about working with Group Policy,

5
00:00:22.630 --> 00:00:25.460
we're normally actually making a lot
of different settings and changes.

6
00:00:25.460 --> 00:00:27.370
But today we're actually taking
a little bit of a detour and

7
00:00:27.370 --> 00:00:30.420
we're actually talking about
using security templates instead.

8
00:00:30.420 --> 00:00:33.450
And actually using that along
with Group Policy as well.

9
00:00:33.450 --> 00:00:34.910
And who better than to help us?

10
00:00:34.910 --> 00:00:36.450
Well, Mr. Mike Rodrick.

11
00:00:36.450 --> 00:00:40.125
Now Mike, security templates
are not exactly Group Policy.

12
00:00:40.125 --> 00:00:41.240
>> Mm-hm.

13
00:00:41.240 --> 00:00:44.790
>> And even though I know Group Policy
can help us, is there a reason for

14
00:00:44.790 --> 00:00:46.290
me to use security templates.

15
00:00:46.290 --> 00:00:47.370
>> Yeah there are.

16
00:00:47.370 --> 00:00:52.570
Security templates are basically a subset
of the settings you'd find in a GPO.

17
00:00:52.570 --> 00:00:54.900
And we'll see what I mean
here in just a second.

18
00:00:54.900 --> 00:00:59.260
So if you were to take a slice of those
settings, and it's the security settings,

19
00:00:59.260 --> 00:01:01.380
hence the name security templates.

20
00:01:01.380 --> 00:01:02.930
Take those out of a GPO,

21
00:01:02.930 --> 00:01:07.340
now I can work with those settings
outside of the group policy environment.

22
00:01:07.340 --> 00:01:09.100
Why would that be advantageous?

23
00:01:09.100 --> 00:01:10.190
Well, I can give somebody,

24
00:01:10.190 --> 00:01:14.740
I could delegate to somebody the job of
creating these security templates and

25
00:01:14.740 --> 00:01:18.300
going through the myriad of settings
that I can configure in there.

26
00:01:18.300 --> 00:01:20.880
But I don't have to give them any
permissions in Active Directory.

27
00:01:20.880 --> 00:01:23.930
I don't have to give them any
permissions inside a Group Policy.

28
00:01:23.930 --> 00:01:26.710
In fact,
they can test it on a local machine.

29
00:01:26.710 --> 00:01:29.500
They can import those
settings into a local policy,

30
00:01:29.500 --> 00:01:34.130
they could configure a machine And
actually compare the settings that are on

31
00:01:34.130 --> 00:01:37.680
the machine with the template and
get it all straightened out and

32
00:01:37.680 --> 00:01:41.720
tested, and then give that template to
somebody that does have permissions in

33
00:01:41.720 --> 00:01:45.320
Active Directory and Group Policy,
and they can simply import.

34
00:01:45.320 --> 00:01:47.830
That template into that GPO.

35
00:01:47.830 --> 00:01:51.710
So that's the big advantage there is being
able to be kinda break it up into smaller

36
00:01:51.710 --> 00:01:55.910
responsibilities and not have to
make somebody's say, an admin, or

37
00:01:55.910 --> 00:01:59.750
give them permissions to create Group
Policy, because if I give them the ability

38
00:01:59.750 --> 00:02:02.310
to create Group Policy,
they can make a policy and

39
00:02:02.310 --> 00:02:06.280
link it somewhere or create policies
that didn't do what we wanted it to do.

40
00:02:06.280 --> 00:02:08.460
Right?
We always talk about principle of least

41
00:02:08.460 --> 00:02:12.870
privilege and that's really where
these security templates come in.

42
00:02:12.870 --> 00:02:14.810
And, they're reusable, right?

43
00:02:14.810 --> 00:02:17.820
Because I'm gonna import
that template into a GPO.

44
00:02:17.820 --> 00:02:20.690
If I need those same
settings in a different GPO,

45
00:02:20.690 --> 00:02:23.780
I can simply import that
template into the GPO.

46
00:02:23.780 --> 00:02:27.970
Editing the template in the future is just
a matter of opening up my snap in and

47
00:02:27.970 --> 00:02:29.540
working with that template.

48
00:02:29.540 --> 00:02:30.800
I don't have to go into Group Policy.

49
00:02:30.800 --> 00:02:33.740
I don't have to remote into domain
controller or anything like that.

50
00:02:33.740 --> 00:02:38.990
I can do it all right here on my Windows
8 or my Windows 7 or my Windows 10 box.

51
00:02:38.990 --> 00:02:41.480
So a few advantages to these templates.

52
00:02:41.480 --> 00:02:44.940
>> Now, Mike,
they actually sound kind of complicated.

53
00:02:44.940 --> 00:02:47.171
Do I have to learn some type of scripting?

54
00:02:47.171 --> 00:02:49.609
Is there anything I really
have to kind of focus in on,

55
00:02:49.609 --> 00:02:51.629
so I can get used to
the security templates?

56
00:02:51.629 --> 00:02:53.160
>> There's not.

57
00:02:53.160 --> 00:02:54.650
They make it really easy.

58
00:02:54.650 --> 00:02:56.250
It's a snap-in that we can use, and

59
00:02:56.250 --> 00:02:58.960
you're probably familiar with
this point at the snap-ins.

60
00:02:58.960 --> 00:03:01.780
Heck, all those Active Directory
tools that we use?

61
00:03:01.780 --> 00:03:06.160
Users and computers, Group Policy
management, those are snap-ins.

62
00:03:06.160 --> 00:03:08.230
They're just prebuilt snap-ins.

63
00:03:08.230 --> 00:03:12.260
But we're going to create our own
custom snap-in, our own custom tool.

64
00:03:12.260 --> 00:03:16.570
Let's take a look at my screen and I'll
show you how to go through this process.

65
00:03:16.570 --> 00:03:21.680
I'm on my windows A1 box and
all I'm going to do is create a blank MMC.

66
00:03:21.680 --> 00:03:26.480
So we're gonna type in MMC, short for
Microsoft Management Console.

67
00:03:26.480 --> 00:03:29.630
That opens up this blank tool and
it should look familiar.

68
00:03:29.630 --> 00:03:34.490
I've got a navigation tree down on the
left hand side, I've got a details area

69
00:03:34.490 --> 00:03:39.050
out here in the middle, and then I've
got an actions pane down the right.

70
00:03:39.050 --> 00:03:41.160
That's like all the other
tools that we use,

71
00:03:41.160 --> 00:03:43.730
and that's the idea about
how fun Microsoft is.

72
00:03:43.730 --> 00:03:46.580
Hey, if all the tools
have the same layout,

73
00:03:46.580 --> 00:03:48.590
you're not confused when you open a tool.

74
00:03:48.590 --> 00:03:49.440
Right?
You know where to go or

75
00:03:49.440 --> 00:03:51.290
what to look for at least.

76
00:03:51.290 --> 00:03:57.220
So if I go, File, Add/Remove Snap-in,
I get a list of snap-ins.

77
00:03:57.220 --> 00:04:01.220
Now, I'm on my Windows 8 machine,
which means I don't have as many, but

78
00:04:01.220 --> 00:04:04.140
if I was on a domain controller,
in fact, here.

79
00:04:04.140 --> 00:04:05.460
Let's just take a look.

80
00:04:05.460 --> 00:04:09.040
Instead of saying what if, hey,
I've got a domain controller here.

81
00:04:09.040 --> 00:04:09.870
I'll show you what I mean.

82
00:04:09.870 --> 00:04:13.410
I could create an MMC over here.

83
00:04:13.410 --> 00:04:16.530
Do a File, Add/Remove Snap-in.

84
00:04:16.530 --> 00:04:19.540
Look, there's Active Directory
using the computers.

85
00:04:19.540 --> 00:04:21.530
There's DNS.

86
00:04:22.740 --> 00:04:25.930
Let's see, I don't have DHCP
installed on this machine.

87
00:04:25.930 --> 00:04:28.960
There's Group Policy Management,
let's see which one that is.

88
00:04:29.960 --> 00:04:31.050
There's Group Policy Management.

89
00:04:31.050 --> 00:04:33.750
We'll add that one and we'll click OK.

90
00:04:33.750 --> 00:04:38.870
And so if these are some of my primary
functions, I now have one tool, right,

91
00:04:38.870 --> 00:04:43.890
this one window that I can work with
Active Directory, I can work with DNS,

92
00:04:43.890 --> 00:04:47.950
and I can work with Group Policy,
all right, all in the same little tool.

93
00:04:47.950 --> 00:04:49.130
I could save this.

94
00:04:49.130 --> 00:04:50.300
For future use.

95
00:04:50.300 --> 00:04:52.980
So that's the big
advantage of those MMCs is

96
00:04:52.980 --> 00:04:55.050
being able to put those snap-ins in there.

97
00:04:55.050 --> 00:04:58.330
Now over here on the client, because I
don't have my remote server admin tools

98
00:04:58.330 --> 00:05:00.720
installed, I don't have
some of those snap-ins.

99
00:05:00.720 --> 00:05:04.270
But if I needed them, I could install the
remote server administration tools, and

100
00:05:04.270 --> 00:05:07.760
I'd have all those same
snap-ins on my client, right?

101
00:05:07.760 --> 00:05:12.250
For us though, for this one, I'm going
to scroll down just a little bit.

102
00:05:12.250 --> 00:05:17.640
And I'm gonna go with security templates
and I'm gonna go ahead and click add and

103
00:05:17.640 --> 00:05:20.410
you know what, we should take a look
at the security configuration and

104
00:05:20.410 --> 00:05:21.950
analysis while we're in there.

105
00:05:21.950 --> 00:05:24.210
We'll add that one too and we'll click OK.

106
00:05:24.210 --> 00:05:29.650
Now I've got my tools and
normally what I would do is I'd save this.

107
00:05:29.650 --> 00:05:34.380
And I might dump it out to my desktop and
call it MyConsole you know or

108
00:05:34.380 --> 00:05:37.590
whatever I want, we'll just say that.

109
00:05:37.590 --> 00:05:41.280
And now that's any time I need to
work with those tools, there it is.

110
00:05:41.280 --> 00:05:43.680
I just launch it up and we're good to go.

111
00:05:43.680 --> 00:05:47.540
Love my MMCs, just a little
detour there for just a second.

112
00:05:47.540 --> 00:05:49.780
So let's get back over to
the security templates.

113
00:05:49.780 --> 00:05:54.800
Now when we talk about security templates,
again its a subset of GPOs.

114
00:05:54.800 --> 00:05:58.400
I don't have any to start with
when I first create this console,

115
00:05:58.400 --> 00:05:59.360
it just has this path.

116
00:05:59.360 --> 00:06:02.410
C:\Users\Administrators, so my profile,

117
00:06:02.410 --> 00:06:06.570
who I'm logged on as
Documents\Security\Templates.

118
00:06:06.570 --> 00:06:11.130
So it's gonna create this folder
structure within my documents folder, and

119
00:06:11.130 --> 00:06:14.438
the first thing I would need to
do is create a new template.

120
00:06:14.438 --> 00:06:17.710
So I right-click on there and
choose New Template.

121
00:06:17.710 --> 00:06:21.730
I'll give it a name, and
I'm gonna call this my, I don't know,

122
00:06:21.730 --> 00:06:25.020
we'll call it ITPro settings or something.

123
00:06:26.050 --> 00:06:29.350
I'll just call it IT pro for
short, and I'll click okay.

124
00:06:29.350 --> 00:06:33.100
So now I got this new
template called ITPro, but

125
00:06:33.100 --> 00:06:36.510
just like a GPO, it's basically blank,
it has a bunch of settings in it,

126
00:06:36.510 --> 00:06:40.960
but they're not configured yet, and if
you look at this, try to remember these,

127
00:06:40.960 --> 00:06:45.860
Account, Local, Event Log, Restricted
Groups, System Services, Registry,

128
00:06:45.860 --> 00:06:48.890
File System, got all those memorized?

129
00:06:48.890 --> 00:06:49.470
Okay.

130
00:06:49.470 --> 00:06:52.850
Now we're gonna switch back
over here to a Group Policy and

131
00:06:52.850 --> 00:06:54.690
I'm going to use my new console,
as a matter of fact.

132
00:06:54.690 --> 00:06:59.630
Right-click on this guy,
soon as I get rid of my little warning,

133
00:07:00.820 --> 00:07:05.620
and choose Edit and underneath Policies
and then Windows Settings, and

134
00:07:05.620 --> 00:07:10.140
then Security Settings,
this should look familiar.

135
00:07:10.140 --> 00:07:13.080
Account, Local, Event Log,
Restricted Groups, System Services,

136
00:07:13.080 --> 00:07:14.540
Registry, File System.

137
00:07:16.970 --> 00:07:18.480
So you see what I'm saying?

138
00:07:18.480 --> 00:07:22.610
This is just a subset of all the settings
that are available in a normal GPU.

139
00:07:22.610 --> 00:07:25.570
So like Ronnie was saying earlier
it just sort of vanished because I

140
00:07:25.570 --> 00:07:27.450
could go to the GPU itself.

141
00:07:27.450 --> 00:07:29.650
And configure all of these
settings right here.

142
00:07:30.780 --> 00:07:33.160
But, the person I want to do this,

143
00:07:33.160 --> 00:07:35.510
doesn't have permission to remote
into the domain controller, or

144
00:07:35.510 --> 00:07:39.540
they don't have RSAT installed, so they
can't get access to Group Policy remotely.

145
00:07:39.540 --> 00:07:43.090
So they can add this snap-in and
they can work with these settings.

146
00:07:43.090 --> 00:07:49.130
All the same settings are there, Account
Policies, my Local Policies, all of that.

147
00:07:49.130 --> 00:07:52.030
All right, so for an example,
I think we're gonna do one called

148
00:07:52.030 --> 00:07:54.353
Restricted Groups,
because this is another one.

149
00:07:54.353 --> 00:07:57.187
Remember lately we've been towards
the end of these episodes.

150
00:07:57.187 --> 00:07:59.621
We've been doing some
common configurations.

151
00:07:59.621 --> 00:08:03.690
Things that we use group policy for
in most network environments.

152
00:08:03.690 --> 00:08:05.220
Restricted groups is another one of those.

153
00:08:05.220 --> 00:08:09.100
It's a setting that is very handy.

154
00:08:09.100 --> 00:08:13.720
What it allows me to do is to
control local group membership.

155
00:08:13.720 --> 00:08:17.460
I can take domain accounts and
domain groups for that matter and

156
00:08:17.460 --> 00:08:20.620
I can add them to local groups.

157
00:08:20.620 --> 00:08:22.211
And think we'll Mike,
you can do that anyway, right?

158
00:08:22.211 --> 00:08:24.545
You can open up computer
management on that machine and

159
00:08:24.545 --> 00:08:26.850
you can add that domain group in there.

160
00:08:26.850 --> 00:08:30.190
But I don't want to have
to do that every time.

161
00:08:30.190 --> 00:08:32.230
In a company I used to work for,

162
00:08:32.230 --> 00:08:37.290
we needed a domain account to be in
the local admin's group on every machine,

163
00:08:37.290 --> 00:08:40.980
so that if they needed to they could
install software and do what have you.

164
00:08:40.980 --> 00:08:44.350
But we reimage the machines every week.

165
00:08:44.350 --> 00:08:49.250
So that meant if I ran around to all 120
machines, added that person into that

166
00:08:49.250 --> 00:08:53.000
group, on each machine one at a time,
that was a lot of work.

167
00:08:53.000 --> 00:08:54.810
And guess what I had to do next week?

168
00:08:54.810 --> 00:08:56.680
>> Do it again.
>> [LAUGHTER] The same thing, right?

169
00:08:56.680 --> 00:08:58.090
All over again.

170
00:08:58.090 --> 00:09:00.340
Whereas restricted groups
is a group policy.

171
00:09:00.340 --> 00:09:04.550
So if I reimage that machine it comes
back online, this policy applies,

172
00:09:04.550 --> 00:09:07.100
and boom, they're in that group again.

173
00:09:07.100 --> 00:09:08.480
I didn't have to do anything.

174
00:09:08.480 --> 00:09:11.584
That's the centralised
configuration management, right?

175
00:09:11.584 --> 00:09:15.554
So I'll right click on restricted
groups and choose add group.

176
00:09:15.554 --> 00:09:19.465
Now when this dialogue box opens, the
first thing I have to do is decide what

177
00:09:19.465 --> 00:09:21.962
group am I trying to
control the membership of?

178
00:09:21.962 --> 00:09:24.322
So I'm going to click browse,
and I want to find,

179
00:09:24.322 --> 00:09:27.210
or I'm sorry I'm not going
to type browse on that one.

180
00:09:27.210 --> 00:09:29.120
I'm just going to do the local
administrators group.

181
00:09:30.950 --> 00:09:33.100
Spell that right, and I'll click OK.

182
00:09:33.100 --> 00:09:37.490
And it opens up the properties for
the local administrators group.

183
00:09:37.490 --> 00:09:38.980
And I've got two options here.

184
00:09:38.980 --> 00:09:45.300
One is members of this group the bottom
one is this group is a member of.

185
00:09:45.300 --> 00:09:46.200
So with the top one,

186
00:09:46.200 --> 00:09:50.770
I'm deciding who's gonna be
a member of the local admins group.

187
00:09:50.770 --> 00:09:56.450
The bottom one is saying the local admins
group is gonna be added to another group,

188
00:09:56.450 --> 00:09:58.960
whatever groups I list there, right.

189
